direction.raw_text: steam shooting out of a huge old half-rusted calliope. The music is very loud and raucous. Moving up and back we see the black awning entrance to the freak tent, where FREDERICK TREVES, Resident Surgeon and Lecturer on anatomy at the London Hospital, is standing with his back to us observing the posters of the freaks. Coming along a muddy walkway at the side of the tent is Treves' wife, ANNE, and their two DAUGHTERS. The shrill over- whelming music seems to engulf her. She looks discomfited, vulnerable, and protective of her daughters. The girls, oblivious to any fear, are finishing their chocolate sweets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . We hear what could be the trumpeting of an elephant. Treves parts the black canvas and enters the main part of the tent. Off to his left he sees a man wrapped in a black cape, holding a conch shell aloft and blowing powerfully into it. The tent is dimly lit with flickering oil lamps. People mill about through the weaving corridors. To Treves' right, he sees a sign reading, "The Deadly Fruit of the Original Sin," over a small, very dark corridor. Treves enters the passage and disappears into the shadows. The corridor has a series of flaps and turns to disorient the spectator. Treves carefully pushes his way through and arrives at the inner chamber. In a roped-off space stands a small stage set at eve-level, with curtains on three sides. On the stage is a bell jar filled with grey-murky fluid lit from behind with casts an eerie glow in the chamber. Suspended in the fluid is the life-sized body of a baby-doll with the attached head of a large snake. At the join of head and body is a blob of unidentifiable organic matter. It is obviously phony, but the effect is still very disquieting. At the bottom of the jar, in the muck, sits an apple with two large bites out of it. Behind the jar is a painting on the order of a religious triptych, portraying Adam on one side, Eve on the other, and the tree flowering over the jar. Treves' impassive face is bathed in the watery glow. He studies the strange object with a critical eye. In the passage we hear movement, and an OLDER GENTLEMAN enters. He seems visibly impressed with "The Deadly Fruit of the Original Sin."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a moment, Treves quietly leaves the inner chamber. As he pushes his way through the corridor, the noise grows and becomes a cacophony of strange sounds. He exits and hears a booming roar and the rush of air as a series of twelve candles, mounted in a row on a ten-foot stand, are blown out by "THE INCREDIBLE WIND-MAN." His BARKER steps up and talks to the people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few people raise their hands. The Barker scans the crowd and then points over the heads of the volunteers to TWO MEN toward the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During the above, The Incredible Wind-Man removes his cape, revealing his great barrel chest and pot-belly supported by spindly, white, hairless legs. As the Barker sets the "Volunteers," the Wind-Man walks about the small platform, huffing and puffing and blowing on the conch shell. The "Volunteers" set, the Wind-Man steps up to the end of the bellows, takes an enormous breath, and twirls his black handlebar moustache as a signal to the Barker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Wind-Man clamps his mouth to the bellows, and with great show begins to exhale, savagely stamping his feet. The Two Lads struggle obviously, and then pretend to be forced apart. The Barker triumphantly lifts the Wind-Man's hand. The Wind- Man ceases to blow, removes his lips from the bellows and the Two Lads instantly collapse together on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd cheers, while the Wind-Man puts the conch shell to his lips and proudly stamps his feet, circling about the Two Lads. Amidst this applause, Treves smiles indulgently. He moves on, looking for something genuine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the crowd, Treves notices a YOUNG BOY staring open-mouthed, blankly at the curtain. Treves pushes through the glut of people to join the Boy and get a better view. The curtain is actually a large canvas. On it is a life-sized portrait, crudely painted, of a creature that could only be possible in a nightmare. It is the figure of a man turning into an elephant. The transformation, however, is not complete; there is still more of the man than beast. Palm trees in the background suggest the jungle habitat in which this Perverted object might have once roamed. Filled with curiosity, Treves moves toward the curtain.

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON HOSPITAL We see a bellows pumping air into the open grate of a cast iron stove. We hear moaning in the background. The coals flare to a fierce glow. From the mouth of the stove protrude the handles of several cauterizing irons, their heads imbedded in the coals. Up above the irons, Treves stands by a waist- high operating table covered with black leather. His face is illuminated by an oil lantern held by a nurse. The room is fairly dark owing to the oppressive overcast sky seen through two windows. There is also a large sink, a cupboard containing dressings, gags, manacles, emetics and other unattractive things, and two hard chairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and two other DOCTORS, MR. FOX and MR. HILL, are present. The two Students are pulling with constant pressure on a rope tied to the patient's leg. Treves and Mr. Fox are working on a chest wound caused by a machine accident. There are gear-wheel marks getting progressively deeper as they near a great open gash. Mr. Hill places a cotton mask over the patient's nose and mouth and applies drops of chloroform. The patient struggles, but soon his moans subside and he is unconscious.
direction.name: direction

The door of the shop is windowless and padlocked. Treves walks into the picture, studies the whole scene for a moment, goes to the shop door and finds that it is padlocked. direction.raw_text: Total darkness. We hear the sound of the padlock being removed. The door opens and light streams in. The canvas covering the windows at the front of the shop obscures all other light. The Owner enters, followed by Treves and the Boy. From his expression, as well as Treves', we can tell there must be an awful stench in the room. No one says a word. The Boy closes the door, while the owner lights a small gas light. We can now see the shop. It it empty, grey with dust, cold and dank. Some old tins and a few shriveled potatoes occupy a shelf. The far end of the shop is blocked off by a curtain suspended from a cord by a few rings. The Owner approaches it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rings rattle back, and the curtain is omen. We see a bent figure crouching on a stool, covered by a brown blanket. In front of it on a tripod is a large brick, heated from below by a bunsen burner. From the blanket protrudes a perfectly normal left arm and hand warming itself over the brick. It does not move when the curtain is drawn. Treves steps closer. The Owner, watching his every move, turns-and smiles at him. He bangs his riding crop on the wall and yells to the crouched figure, as if speaking to a dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Boy, excited by his own fear, mimics the Owner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The figure comes forward and lets the blanket fall to the ground and we see the ELEPHANT MAN himself. Treves, his eyes wide with horror and wonder, his mouth frozen open, steps backward in an instinctive movement of self preservation. The Owner laughs. The Elephant Man is naked to the waist, his feet are bare and he wears a pair of worn trousers from a fat man's dress suit. He is a little below average height, and looks shorter from the bowing of his back. His head is enormous and misshapen, as big around as a man's waist. From his brow projects a huge boney mass, almost obscuring his right eye. His nose is a nose of flesh, recognizable only from its position. From the upper jaw projects another mass of bone protruding from the mouth like a stump, turning the upper lip inside out, making a slobbering aperture. It almost gives the impression of a rudimentary trunk or tusk. On top of his head is a handful of lank, black hair. At the back of it hangs a bag of spongy skin, resembling cauliflower. These loathsome growths cover his back and hang down to the middle of his thighs. The right arm is enormous and shapeless, the hand like a knot of tuberous roots. His left arm is not only normal, but delicately shaped, with fine skin and a hand that any woman might envy. From his chest hangs another bag of flesh, like the dewlap of a lizard. His legs are also grossly deformed, his feet great stumps. Behind him, as painted in the portrait, are two crudely constructed palm trees. The Owner harshly raps again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Elephant Man begins to turn. The boy filled with malicious glee at seeing the monster obey, screams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Elephant Man completes his turn and comes to rest. We see a CLOSE-UP of the Elephant Man looking at Treves. His face is utterly devoid, and incapable, of expression. We see the Elephant Man's eyes. He closes them.

dialogue.raw_text: Here we are sir. (ticking it off by rote) Life is full of surprises. Ladies and gentlemen, consider the fate of this creature's poor mother. dialogue.raw_text: Ah... yes. Um, first I would like to ask you a few questions, would that be all right?

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Now, let's see. Your Owner... um, the man who... who looks after you tells me that you are English and your name is John Merrick. Is that correct?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know where you were born? Where you come from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I tell you what, I'll ask you a question, and you shake your head like this for "no" and nod like this for "yes", alright? Do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you in any pain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um, no. Just nod your head like this for "yes" and shake it like this for "no". Now, are you in any pain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are your parents still alive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you understand? Are they dead? Your father... your mother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Freddie, what you doing for... I say do open a window in here or...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm dreadfully sorry, I had no idea that... I say!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves and Fox are standing outside the door to Treves' office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves turns to go back in, then stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes back in, shutting the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good Lord, Freddie! What have you got in there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll know presently. At the meeting of the society. But until then, I beg of you Fox, keep it to yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly, if you insist. You must have quite a find there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what I've got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing of any importance, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell you this much, Fox, it's beyond anything you or I have ever dealt with. Keep it to yourself, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves turns the key in the door. He turns to the chair the figure had been occupying, but he is not there. The figure is hiding in the corner, crouched behind a black frock operating coat, so stiff with dried blood and pus it stands up by itself. Treves looks quickly around the room and finally sees him. He looks at the figure for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The frightened figure just crouches there looking at him. Treves goes to him, pulls him up and over to the chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The figure sits. Treves pauses uncertainly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The figure does nothing. Treves moves to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The figure leans back fearfully. From behind him we see just the top of his wide hooded head. Treves, standing before him, lifts the hood up and back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit... down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I'll examine you now. I'll save the questions for later... Will you take off your hat now, please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be frightened, I simply want to look at you. Do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (more to himself) That's right, don't be frightened. Don't be frightened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - LONDON HOSPITAL We see two cameras set up, their OPERATORS next to them staring at something we cannot see. Treves stands beside them concentrating on the same sight. All three are speechless. Treves suddenly remembers himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cameramen mumble, "Yes", and gratefully disappear beneath the black cloths of their cameras.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They trigger the flash powder. In the blinding flashes we briefly see the silhouette of a tremendously bulky figure, starting at the light.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: PATHOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF LONDON BRIGHT LIGHT

direction.raw_text: - PATHOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF LONDON BRIGHT LIGHT As we pull back and down in a slow spiral we see the light is coming through high windows. We now see several rows of distinguished doctors talking to each other in anticipation. As we continue to spiral down we see Treves before them at a podium. Behind him are two ASSISTANTS standing beside a curtained stall. Treves raps a pointer stick on the podium to bring the meeting to order. We move behind the stall as the Assistants part the curtains and we see the silhouette of the Elephant Man. The doctors talk among themselves quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves' voice fades as we DISSOLVE TO the Doctors, who at first were rigid and flustered, and now bent forward, concentrating, obviously consumed with interest. Spiraling down again we see Treves finishing his lecture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves nods to the Assistants and they go to the Elephant Man. We see them in shadow untying the loose knot of the loin cloth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He is English, he is twenty-one years of age and his name is John Merrick. Gentlemen, in the course of my profession I have come upon lamentable deformities of the face due to injury or disease, as well as mutilations and contortions of the body, depending upon like causes; but, at no time have I met with such a dreaded or perverted version of a human being as this man. I wish to draw your attention to the insidious conditions affecting this patient. Note, if you will, the extreme enlargement of the skull... and upper limb, which is totally useless. The alarming curvature of the spine... Turn him, please... the looseness of the skin, and the varying fibrous tumors that cover 90% of the body.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...And there is every indication that these afflictions have been in existence, and have progressed rapidly, since birth. The Patient also suffers from chronic bronchitis. As an interesting side-note, in spite of the afore-mentioned anomalies, the patient's genitals remain entirely intact and unaffected.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -UP of the shadow of the head of the Elephant Man. It goes up for a breath.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So then, gentlemen, owing to this series of deformities: The congenital exostoses of the skull; extensive papillomatous growths and large pendulous masses in connection with the skin; the great enlargement of the right upper limb, involving all the bones; the massive distortion of the head and the extensive areas covered by papillomatous growth, the patient has been called, "The Elephant Man."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Elephant Man (hereafter the E.M.) wearing his cloak, is seated by the desk. Treves stands behind him, measuring his head with calipers. He removes the calipers and notes the span, then sets them on the desk. He places the hood over the E.M.'s head. Treves sits at his desk and makes some final notes. He becomes more absorbed in his notes than in the E.M. The E.M. makes an unintelligible sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The E.M. is silent. Treves, only now realizing that the E.M. has said something, looks up at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The E.M. is silent. Treves passes it off as a sigh and turns back to his work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He closes his notebook and rises. He remembers something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He exits. The E.M. is alone. He rises and shuffles slowly about, investigating the room. He goes to the desk and begins touching things, including the calipers. He notices the card Treves gave to the Owner tucked in the back pages. He pauses for a moment and then takes the card. His hand disappears into the cloak, and he moves back into the corner behind the stiff, black operating coat. Treves re-enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The E.M. takes up his stick and follows Treves out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hmm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's been a long day for everyone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes, you'll need a cab... (to the E.M.) Stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON HOSPITAL We see Treves and Fox alone at a window. They are looking down on the hospital square Treves had previously crossed and see the E.M., lit by gaslight and moving to a waiting cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The E.M., as he is getting into the cab, stops, turns and looks to the upper stories of the hospital. Treves and Fox are joined by three laughing colleagues who clap Treves on the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From the upper story we watch the cab drive away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From outside the window we see Treves surrounded by his laughing friends.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You never mentioned his mental state.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's imbecile, no doubt from birth. He speaks, but... it's all gibberish. No, the man's a homeless idiot... (to himself) I pray God he's an idiot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite a coup, Freddie. You'll look splendid in the journal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where ever did you find that creature?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It's a pity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I pity the poor cab driver, myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a door. It opens and Treves walks in. He shuts the door, locks it, goes to a coat rack on the wall and hangs up his overcoat and hat. He notices his reflection in a mirror and examines himself wearily. Anne's smiling reflection appears beside his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We move past Anne's reflection to a CU of Treves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did it go well, darling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, very well, I think. Are the girls in bed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, and they send their kisses. Would you like your sherry now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I think a whiskey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We now see a bunsen burner roar of flame reflected in Bytes' eyes. Pulling back we see Bytes, quite drunk, sitting, cooking sausages over the hot brick. He takes another drink from his gin bottle. Up comes a wet belch and he takes another drink. The E.M. is crouched against the wall with a bowl of potatoes and a cup of water in front of him. With his good hand, he is picking tiny pieces of potato and feeding himself. The eating is fairly loud and animal-like. The drinking is even worse. The Boy is across the room asleep, wrapped in ragged little blankets. The E.M. takes a drink of water, making a loud smacking, slurping sound. Bytes looks up from his cooking with a smoldering look, just waiting for him to make the sound again. He does and Bytes takes his crop and violently jabs him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bytes takes a mouthful of gin and mockingly slurps it mimicking the E.M.'s sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The E.M. picks and eats some more and then drinks again very tentatively. Because of his fear the water catches in his throat and he spits and coughs out onto the floor, gasping and wheezing for breath. Bytes is up and whacks him with his riding crop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The E.M. struggles to get up, carrying his food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He jabs the E.M. again, spilling his potatoes and water onto the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes the E.M. again, then slips on the potatoes and falls heavily to the floor, crying out in shock. Then rage hits him. The E.M. backs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Boy wakes up in fear. Bytes moves quickly toward the E.M. raising his crop. The E.M. stumbles and falls backward onto the floor. His head goes back and he begins gasping for air. Bytes yanks him up and hits him in the face with his riding crop. The force of the blow knocks a glob of spit into the air from the E.M.'s mouth. The E.M. gasps and wheezes horribly as Bytes hits him again and again. From across the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bytes goes right on with the beating.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Belt up, you misbegotten garbage. (mumbling to himself) How can I eat with that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (yelling) How can I eat with THAT?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Out of my sight!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not satisfied with his speed)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You clumsy sod!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bytes! DON'T...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This won't do, my lad. This just won't do!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - LONDON HOSPITAL We see the eyes of the Boy. As we pull back from them, they widen with recognition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of the Receiving Room. Treves has entered and the Boy walks quickly up to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Our man is sick. Come right away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like this. (he breathes heavily in and out to demonstrate the E.M.'s difficulty)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll get my bag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We hear the sound of wheezing coming from the E.M. who is sitting propped up against the stage, wrapped in a blanket. His head bent forward toward his knees. Bytes is going to the door as it opens and the Boy leads Treves in. Treves immediately goes to the E.M.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves pulls the blanket away from the E.M. exposing several bruises and bloody cuts. Treves freezes at the sight and slowly turns to look at Bytes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up at the riding crop in the hand of Bytes, then to the strangely nervous and silent Boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves turns his attention to the E.M. He lifts his head higher and examines the E.M.'s eyes. The E.M., who had been oblivious up until this point, looks into Treves' eyes and recognizes him. With his good hand, he reaches up and touches Treves' arm almost as if appealing to him. Treves' eyes lock on his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bytes considers and then snaps his fingers at the Boy who runs out. He then breaks into an ingratiating grin and leans down over Treves who busily examines the wheezing E.M.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves, uncomfortable, rises. Bytes grips his hand and with the other gathers the material of his sleeve in a slow deliberate squeeze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MORNING - AERIAL SHOT LOOKING DOWN ON HOSPITAL SQUARE Through a window we see Treves and the E.M. walking through a back gate and across the square. MR. CARR GOMM, Hospital Chairman, turns and moves away from the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What did you do to him? He's been like this all night!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was fine when he left here, and now look at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I intend to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He fell. (guardedly) He falls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He must have taken quite a fall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a clumsy git. Never watches where he is going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why is he sitting up like this? He needs rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the way he sleeps. If he lays down, he'll die. (he points to his neck and leans his head back) Head's too heavy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This man belongs in hospital.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (apprehensively) Can't you fix him up here? ...He's my livelihood. Listen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You listen, you're not going to have much of a livelihood if this man dies. He's got the rale, he's very weak, and I don't know how much damage has been done by his "fall". Now stop wasting time and fetch a cab.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I really appreciate this, guv. You know, there's lot of things that I can do for you. I move in the proper circles, for this type of thing... (motioning toward the E.M.) In fact, anything at all, if you take my meaning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like doing business with you. You and I understand each other, completely. I know I can trust you. Can't I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gazing at him levelly) Everything will be seen to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is pushing a cart filled of empty breakfast trays down the hall. She glances into the stairwell and sees Treves and the E.M. coming through the door. She continues on, startled by the sight of the mysterious hooded figure. At the end of the hall, she goes into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves and the E.M. are laboriously climbing a flight of stairs. The E.M. is puffing and wheezing with the effort. Treves supports him under his right arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nora enters with the cart and waits for it to be restocked. She leans out the door for another look, but the hall is empty. A Nurse ladles mush into bowls. There is a lot of activity in the kitchen. Nora takes the cart stacked with full trays and pushes it out the door and down the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves and the E.M. cross the hallway and head up a narrow stairway towards the attic. There is a sign reading "Isolation". Carr Gomm is leaning out the door to his office, unseen by Treves. He closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LONDON HOSPITAL - MORNING It is a long, high ceilinged room with large windows along one wall. Beds run the length of both sides of the room. It is a woman's ward and nurses are serving the patients breakfast. Nora enters and nurses take trays from her cart. Nora's mind is on what she has just seen. We see Mothershead come in the door behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mothershead walks on, as Nora now very flustered, picks up a tray.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (startling Nora) Nora! Mind your duties... if you don't concentrate dear, you'll only make more work for the rest of us. Now, get about your business. (pauses, seeing Nora's collar) ...and do get your collar straight, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fumbling with her collar) I'm so sorry, Mrs. Mothershead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do get on with it, Nora.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of a bottle of dark fluid and a bottle of light fluid. Treves mixes the two in a glass. We are in a small oddly shaped room off the attic ward. There is one tiny barred window located high up on the far wall. There is also a bed, two hard chairs and a table. The E.M. is sitting on the bed in shadow and his disguise is now hanging from a peg on the wall beside him. He is still wheezing and appears to be very weak. Treves serves the mixture to the E.M., who sputters and gags on it, but manages to get it down. Treves goes to the table and puts the two bottles in his bag. He goes to the door and turns to the E.M.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two men just look at each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know if you will understand this, but you will never go back to that man again. You're safe now. No one will ever harm you. Do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - LONDON HOSPITAL Treves enters the kitchen and nicks up a bowl. A NURSE ladles some porridge for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves exits and the nurses admiringly watch him go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Breakfasting with the patients this morning, Mr. Treves?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's for a patient.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves climbs the stairs onto the landing. Down the hall, Mr. Carr Gomm is walking toward his office. Treves tries not to be seen, but to no avail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves hesitates, trying to hide the bowl, but gives up and goes down the hall to meet Carr Gomm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm calls a Nurse from a nearby ward over. It is Nora. He takes the bowl from Treves and hands it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gestures toward his office door. As he and Treves enter the office, Nora looks apprehensively up the isolation ward stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves, come over here a moment, won't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Treves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (seeing the bowl) You've acquired a taste for this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's quite nutritious, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be mad. This muck can kill you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take this up, to to the man in the isolation ward when you have a moment, won't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (apprehensively) Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be frightened. He won't hurt you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indeed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CARR GOMM'S OFFICE It is a small, elegantly furnished room with a large window. The two men sit, Carr Gomm behind his desk and Treves in a leather chair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A hospital is no place for secrecy, Mr. Treves. Doctors spiriting hooded figures about are liable to cause comment. Why wasn't this patient properly admitted, and why is he in isolation? Is he contagious?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No sir, he's got bronchitis and he's been badly beaten.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why isn't he in the General Ward, then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well sir, he's quite seriously deformed, and I fear the other patients would find him... rather shocking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Deformed? Is that it. Then am I to assume that he is ultimately incurable?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are your plans then, Treves... You are aware that the London does not accept incurables. The rules are quite clear on that point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I'm well aware of that. But this case is quite exceptional.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, is he a friend of yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, more of an acquaintance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: AND STAIRWAY (B) CARR GOMM'S OFFICE (C) (A) The E.M. is asleep in his sleeping posture on the bed. (B) Nora, with the bowl, is climbing the stairs to the attic ward. She pauses in sight of the door and looks apprehensively at it. She begins to hum to give herself courage, and continues up the stairs. (A) The E.M. awakens, hears the footsteps, and now the humming, which grows in volume. He becomes fearful and reaches for his cloak. The humming stops. He freezes and listens. (C) Treves and Carr Gomm seated as before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (B) Nora stands outside the door, listening. She is barely breathing. (A) The E.M., still listening, slowly lets his hand drop away from the cloak. (B) Nora opens the door. (A) The E.M. grabs for the cloak as the door swings open flooding him with light. We see him for the first time in his entirety. CU of Nora screaming and dropping the tray. CU of the caught E.M. (C) The shrill scream is heard from upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves rushes out. Carr Gomm just sits for a moment, thinking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I certainly sympathize with your problem, Treves... Why don't you try the British Home, or the Royal Hospital for perhaps they would have a place for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir, I'll look into that. (he rises) Would you like to meet him sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Elephant Man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves, rushing up the stairs, reaches the landing. Nora is at the railing, crying. The door is open, the breakfast tray littering the floor. The E.M. is on the bed trying to squeeze into the corner. Treves quickly closes the door and tries to comfort Nora.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drying her eyes, she goes downstairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, my dear, I should have warned you. I'm so terribly sorry, please forgive me. There, you're alright now. Go downstairs and please ask Mrs. Mothershead to come up. Tell her to knock on the door and wait for me. Alright?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes Sir. I'm sorry, Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Closing the door, Treves steps over the spilt breakfast and goes to the E.M.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The E.M. makes a garbled sound. Treves, alone with the E.M., once more finds himself becoming uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The E.M. is silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves puts out a comforting hand to the E.M. who flinches back. The two men just look at each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very sorry about that. Are you resting well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah good. Well then... oh yes, we'll have to get you some more food. I'm sure you must be simply famished. Hmm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course you are. Now then, I think you'll be quite comfortable up here for awhile. I'll see to it you have everything you need, and, uh... yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Several Nurses are taking bath things off a cart. At the other end of the room, Mothershead is talking to a patient. Nora enters and walks over to Mothershead. They talk, and Mothershead exits. Nora joins the other nurses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Nora's face. She is silent.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you see him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mothershead knocks on the door. Treves opens it, comes out onto the landing and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves opens the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, Mothershead. How are you feeling today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suspiciously) Fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Excellent. Now then, Mrs. Mothershead, I want you to come into this room with me. Inside there is a man with a rather... unfortunate appearance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've heard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes... Well, I want you to clear up a little mess, a breakfast tray was spilt. And bring up another breakfast. When you've done that, you and I shall give the man a bath. But, Mothershead, I'm counting on your many years of experience to get you through this, Above all, do not scream, do not cry out, or in any way show this man that you are frightened of him...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, you don't have to worry about me. I'm not the sort to cry out. Shall we go in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes... Yes, let's go in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mothershead goes right to the mess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick looks up to Mothershead, then averts his eyes. He looks back at her and sees she has no difficulty being in his presence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the E.M., hereafter Merrick) I would like you to meet Mrs. Mothershead - Mrs. Mothershead, Mr. John Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: At the door of Merrick's attic room stand two buckets of very dirty water. We hear footsteps coming up stairs and see a young porter carrying two buckets of clean, steaming water. He puts them down, knocks on the door, and takes the dirty water downstairs. The door opens, Mrs. Mothershead picks up the steaming buckets and takes them inside, shutting the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick's seated in a tin bathtub trying to hide his nakedness. Mrs. Mothershead pours the water in. She scrubs his back with obvious distaste, but does her job. Months of filth and accumulated excrescence are turning the bath water a murky black. As Mothershead scrubs, Merrick slowly leans forward in the bath, closing his eyes, apparently oblivious to his surroundings. Treves sits beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick's eyes flicker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick flinches and pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves leans forward and looks at Merrick. Merrick grows still, his eyes closed, apparently in a reverie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this word, Merrick begins to babble wildly. Obviously alarmed, he thrashes about in the tub, spilling water onto the floor. Treves, alarmed now himself, attempts to calm Merrick, who, still babbling, tries to rise from the tub. Mothershead clamps a hand on Merrick's left arm. At her touch, he is instantly subdued, at least physically. He sinks back into the tub and begins to weep. Treves and Mothershead are astounded by the tears rolling down Merrick's cheeks. They stand motionless looking down at the agonized, naked elephant man.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The disease is shocking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wonder how far it can go before it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit still. Don't wiggle about like a pup. I won't stand for any foolishness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It's pretty certain that if he had the disease as a child, he was abandoned. But in that case, he'd have to have had care. The very fact that he's alive bears that out... (cut to Treves) But, where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The workhouse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes! The workhouse!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) The workhouse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - ALLEY The young PORTER is exiting with great difficulty through a large iron door carrying the two buckets. He sets one of the buckets down, takes the other and splashes it out into the alley. Some thick sludge dribbles from the empty bucket. Unseen by him, the NIGHT PORTER is standing just to the side and he now comes forward. The young Porter seems nervous in his presence. The Night Porter looks at his spattered shoes, then up to the Young Porter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly the Night Porter kicks the other bucket of filthy water violently, sending it splashing all over the young Porter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lets his cigarette drop to the ground, then stamps and grinds it with his brass-heeled boot, all the while smiling. Then he turns on his heel and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Dark clouds rolling through an evening sky.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FOLLOWING BUCKETS OF DIRTY WATER DOWN A HALLWAY BACK ENTRANCE

dialogue.raw_text: What's all this, then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves is scrubbing his Elephant Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Elephant Man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... I hear it's a real horror. Even made Mothershead scream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Friend of the night, eh? The Elephant Man. I think I'll have me a look at that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, you need the scrubbing, ducks!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Through the high barred window, we see the dark sky. The E.M. is on his bed in his sleeping posture. A dim gaslight burns in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -UP of his head on the points of his knees. His breathing is more regular now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lights are being turned off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lights go off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Large iron door is closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Half the lights go off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nurses leave for their quarters - half the lights go off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear the slow metallic footfalls of the Night Porter's boots. He appears and walks into a darkened women's ward. The women are all asleep. Some coughing fitfully, others moaning quietly. The Night Porter walks down the aisle between the beds. We see several of the sleeping women as he passes them. Finally, he comes to a young beautiful woman, her eyes wide open, watching him with intense fear. On either side of her are two very ancient women, snoring deeply. The young woman has her arms tied, suspended in traction above her. The Night Porter moves to her, his shadow engulfing her. She starts to move, rattling the apparatus above her. The Porter puts a finger to his lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns her head away, closing her eyes. He moves in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hush, love, I told you before one word from me, they'll toss you back on the street, and then those pretty little arms of yours will never grow straight. Now close your eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -UP of a gas light in a hallway. The leaping flame makes a low roar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somewhere a door is opened and the squeak sounds vaguely like the trumpeting of an elephant. We hear again the metallic footfalls of the Night Porter's boots, and he appears. He goes to the narrow stairway marked, "Isolation". He stops and casually looks about. He takes a swig of his gin, then starts up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick as before the light is very dim. We hear the echoing footfalls of the Night Porter coming up the stairs. Merrick's head immediately comes up from his knees. As it does, a small object falls from where his head rested. He picks it up and puts it in a pocket of his cloak. it is the portrait of the beautiful woman, which he saw in his dream. Suddenly the door swings open and the Night Porter, bottle in hand, is standing there. He walks into the room and sees Merrick's shape on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns up the light and sees Merrick clearly. The Night Porter jumps back, awe struck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is trembling. The Night Porter, hardly able to believe his eyes, moves slowly toward Merrick. He is afraid but as he reaches the bed, Merrick flinches back. The Night Porter grins, his fear gone now. He is in control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick cowers as far away from the Night Porter as possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a big swallow of the gin and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He offers Merrick his bottle with a swift, almost jabbing motion. Merrick pulls away from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tentatively presses the bottom of the bottle up against the hanging growth on Merrick's chest. Encouraged, he touches him with his fingers. Merrick makes a small whimpering sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves to the door and turns.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here he is, the old fiend of the night, the terror of the London. Let's have a look at you. Let's see what makes 'em scream...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cor Blimey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So this is the Elephant Man. I ain't never seen nothing like you before. What the bleedin' hell happened to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... dumb, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. I likes people what can keep quiet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like a drink? Go on... Go on have some. No? You should try being more sociable, mate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) You and I are going to be good friends, we are. And, I've got lots of friends who I know would like to meet you. And they will, mate... they will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -UP of Night Porter's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves out the door and it closes. In the bed, Merrick looks at the door with terror as the heavy footfalls of the Night Porter recede down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Welcome to the London.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a horse's head in CU, snorting steam into the chill morning air. The horse is harnessed to a milk wagon parked in front of the London. Through the open back of the wagon we see the MILKMAN, and past him Treves, walking towards us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves walks up the path into the hospital.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here early again, eh Mr. Treves? If you don't mind my saying so, sir, with your early habits, you'd 'a made a fine milkman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Charley. I'll keep that in mind!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves, carrying a bowl, crosses the upper hall and starts to the narrow stairway to the Isolation Ward. Over his shoulder we see him knock twice on the door. As the door swings open, the camera pushes past him and we see the room. The lamp is still burning, but Merrick is nowhere to be seen. Treves enters, looking about for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's movement in the corner beside the bed. Merrick rises slightly from the shadow. The light from the lamp hits his frightened eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves is unsettled by the sight of Merrick cowering down on the floor. Merrick begins to babble. Treves enters the room, placing the bowl on the table and going to Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He helps Merrick up onto the bed and goes back to the table for the bowl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has turned back to the bed, but Merrick has slipped to the floor again, still trying to hide himself in the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts the bowl down again and goes back to Merrick, who seems very upset at leaving his hiding place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to help Merrick up, but Merrick just presses himself farther back in the corner, still babbling. There are two raps at the door. Treves goes to it and lets Mothershead in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both look at the bed. Merrick has almost disappeared under it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes to Merrick and takes hold of his left wrist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts to force him up from the floor. Merrick is moaning now, still trying to get away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By this time Mothershead has almost got him back on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They help Merrick settle back on the pillow. Merrick is still making desperate, unintelligible sounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She exits. Treves shuts the door behind her and turns back to the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to the bed and sits down in front of Merrick, angered by his own seeming uselessness in the situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick hesitates, then starts babbling again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slowly Merrick nods yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves carefully mouths the word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is still hesitant, from years of fear, but his eyes betray a growing excitement. Slowly, he tries to talk, his voice a tremulous whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throughout their dialogue, Merrick is still very garbled, but he no longer babbles. He makes a great effort to speak slowly, to form words the way Treves forms them, to be understood.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Merrick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ....Good morning... John. I've brought your breakfast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing down there? Come up John, come up on the bed. The cold floor is bad for you. I won't hurt you, come on now...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must eat. We must keep your strength...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...What on earth is the matter with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now please, John, you must do as I say. Come up from there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. Treves. It'll be his bath-time soon. Has he eaten?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not quite yet, Mrs. Mothershead. There seems to be some difficulty this morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Won't come out, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, he's very upset about something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just being obstinate, sir. I'll handle it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alright, my son, none of this fuss. Come up from there, this instant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! Don't pull at him like that. We don't want to frighten him more than he already is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honestly, sir, you must be very firm with this sort. Otherwise they'd lay about on the floor gibbering all day long. All he understands is a good smack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's had his share of "smacks", Mothershead. I expect that's what drives him under the bed. We must use patience and understanding with this man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps you've got the time for that, Mr. Treves, I certainly don't. I've got an entire hospital to look after, and you have your real patients. Don't waste your time with him sir, it's like talking to a wall. I don't mean to be harsh, but truthfully what can you do for him? I'll be back later for his bath. And Mr. Carr Gomm would like to see you when you have a moment. Good day sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) What good am I to you...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...What is my purpose? ...It's so important that I understand you. I want to help you, I want to be your doctor... (directly to Merrick) but I can't help you unless you help me, unless I know what you are feeling. I believe there's something back there, there's something you want to say, but I've got to understand you. Do you understand me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! You are going to talk to me! We are going to show them! We're going to show them that you're not a wall. We are going to talk! Do you understand? Nod your head if you understand me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You do understand me! You understand. Now you're going to say it. I've got to hear how you say things. Now, very slowly, say "yes."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Yes."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yyyy... Yyye... yyyess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grabbing Merrick's arm) Yes John!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Yyes
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yyyess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yyess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's much better. I could understand that "yes".
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleased) Yes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very good! Oh yes! Now listen. I'm going to say some things to you and I want you to repeat them... um... I want you to say them back to me. Do you understand? I'm going to say some things to you and I want you to say them back to me. Do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excellent! Now, say... "Hello"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name is...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My... name is...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John... Merrick
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say "Merrick".
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Merrick...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say "Mmmerrick."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mmmerrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say "Mmmerrick."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mmmerrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's alright. I understand you. Now, say the whole thing again, Hello ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (haltingly) Hello... my name is... John Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Mothershead comes out of the kitchen with a supper tray and walks down the hall, passing the open ward door. We see nurses serving patients their supper. Nora comes out of the ward with a tray which she holds tightly against her. A bowl of soup is spilling on her apron. She catches up with Mothershead. They speak as they walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mothershead continues on. Nora guiltily watches her go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mrs. Mothershead, please forgive my behavior yesterday. I'm sorry if you're having to do extra work on my account. It was just seeing it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Patients here are not "its". They are either "he's" or "she's", but that's alright, Ireland. This one's going to be more work for all of us. Good God girl! Mind your broth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves and Merrick are absorbed in their work. A knock comes at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mothershead enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Mothershead sets the tray down beside Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and Mothershead exit. Merrick watches the door close. He sighs quietly, looks about, and sees the Bible on the bedside table. He picks it up and, gently runs his fingers over the cover.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, my dear Mrs. Mothershead, how good of you to join us. Mr. Merrick, will you please introduce yourself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitantly) Hello, my name is John Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good Lord, Mr. Treves!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exuberantly) We've made tremendous strides today, Mothershead. He listens and repeats with great attention, and this certainly isn't easy for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Parrots can do as much, Mr. Treves. It's all very nice, but I don't see the point. You know they won't let him stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lowering his voice) I'm sure that if Mr. Merrick made a good impression on the hospital committee they'd see that he's the exception to their rule. Now I'm not expecting miracles. I'm not saying he'll be able to read or write, but I do think that I can get him to speak for himself. I'm going to arrange things with Carr Gomm right now. (to Merrick) That was very good, John, very good. That's all for today. We shall do some more tomorrow. Mothershead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see you soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON There is total pandemonium in the receiving room. The room is filled with screaming men, women and children. Two drunken women have been fighting with broken bottles and are now covered with blood and cuts. The women are still hysterical, one minute they're sobbing, then in an instant screaming and intent upon fighting again. The crowd keeps them apart. Two Bobbies stand in the background making no move to intercede. To the side we see Bytes watching everything. It is still too violent a scene for the Nurses to come to the women's aide and they stand up in the front of the room waiting. Bytes makes his way along the side of the crowd waiting for a chance to get behind the Nurses and on into the hospital. Now the women begin sobbing again and things quiet some. The Nurses come forward into the crowd. Bytes moves over closer to the hallways. When the Nurses have all gone into the crowd he seizes the chance and disappears into the hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Bytes appears and walks down hospital hallway looking about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens and Treves enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves sits in the armchair. Carr Gomm is sitting at his desk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Ah, Treves...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you contacted the British Home and the Royal Hospital?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, no sir. I had planned to see them in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good! How is the patient?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's doing very well. In fact that's why I came to see you. I think that if I were to present Mr. Merrick to the hospital committee, then they would have a chance to see for themselves not only the extraordinary nature of the disease, but of the man as well. If the committee had a chance to speak with him, hear him say a few words for himself, I'm sure they would see him as a patient, rather than as a violation of the rules.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A few words? I thought he was imbecile?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well sir, perhaps I should explain...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I really don't think that's necessary Treves. I'm quite sure the committee will be able to make an equitable decision on the merits of the case, such as they are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't agree. No one can make a reasonable decision about this man's future without at least meeting him. No doctor would presume to diagnose a patient he had never met.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Treves, it's out of the question. Now if it was up to me, I'd say "Certainly, let's meet the fellow, by all means," I'm sorry, I simply can't speak for the other members of the committee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then will you meet him, as a representative of the committee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves, it's out of the question. I want to hear as soon as possible what the other hospitals can do. I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - STAIRCASE - THE LONDON We see Treves leave Carr Gomm's office and walk toward us to the stairwell. As Treves begins down the stairs, he sees Bytes on the next landing coming up. Bytes spots him and goes toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now we see Carr Gomm standing above them, at the top of the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Livid, Bytes looks from Carr Gomm to Treves, at a loss for words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He backs slowly down to the landing eyeing Treves and Carr Gomm. At the landing he casually turns and disappears down more stairs. Treves turns and gazes at Carr Gomm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They part company. We follow Treves down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we follow Carr Gomm to his office door. He stops short.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want my man back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a moment, how did you get in here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind that, I want my man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's still very sick. Please come downstairs with me. I'll explain the situation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... Don't muck me about. You've had plenty of time to fix him up, and he's leaving with me, NOW. Do you understand me? Now, Mr. Treves. We had a bargain!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You misunderstood. This man suffered a severe fall, if you take my meaning. He's my patient now and I must do what...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pull the other one, why don't you! We made a deal!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what you've done to him and he's never going back to that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a freak! That's how they live. We're partners, him and I, business partners. You're willfully deprivin' me of my livlihood!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All you do is profit from another man's misery!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think you're better 'n me? YOU wanted the freak to show all your doctor chums and make a name for yourself, you guv. So I gave him to you. On trust, in the name of science! And now I want him back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't own this man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want him back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you can beat him? So you can starve him? A dog in the street would fare better with you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got my rights, damn you, and I'm going to the authorities!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Well, go to the authorities...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By all means do so. In fact, I'll fetch them myself. I'm quite sure they'd be very interested in your story, as well as ours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now I think we really do understand one another.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (venomously) Right... Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Singularly unpleasant chap... uh... I don't suppose there would be any harm in my meeting your... patient, Mr. Treves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gratefully) Thank you very much Sir. Shall we say in a few days then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shall we say two o'clock tomorrow afternoon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slightly taken aback) Wh... whatever is most convenient for you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two o'clock then... you know Treves... It seems this acquaintance of yours has become rather more than just an acquaintance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Yes, Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (muttering) Two o'clock?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mumbling out loud) Elephant Man? I don't want to meet an Elephant Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON (NIGHT) Again, the hospital is closing down for the night. Lights go off in each hallway. The staff is vacating the hospital. As the last light goes off, we hear the great iron door slam shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - BEDROOM (NIGHT) Anne is at her dressing table, brushing out her hair. She is in a very flattering dressing gown, ready to turn in. We see her reflected in the mirror as well as Treves who is in his robe in the background seated at his side of their bed, deep in thought. Anne looks at Treves and smiles affectionately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Getting no response she renews her efforts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anne puts down the brush and rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anne, sympathizing with his concerns goes to him and puts her arms around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She releases Treves and lies down. Treves realizes that perhaps he has been unkind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anne sits back up and gently places her hand over Treves' mouth. As she does so she leans forward and turns out the light.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (coyly) Freddie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Freddie?... Freddie, don't look so discouraged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I shouldn't be. We made great progress today. I taught him to repeat a few basic phrases. He did rather well, too, but I had to lead him every step of the way. Though frankly, at times I was unsure of who was leading whom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I wasn't sure whether he was parroting me because that's all he was capable of, or whether he sensed that that's all I wanted to hear, and he was trying to please me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I thought you said that he was rather... simple?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is. I mean, I've always thought he was. I think he must be. Is he simple? Or is that just something I've wished upon him to make things simpler for myself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frederick, why are you so interested in this particular case?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. I can't explain it. If this is an intelligent man, trapped in the body of a monster, then I'm under a moral obligation to help free that mind, free that spirit as best I can, to help him live as full and content a life as possible. But! If he's an imbecile, who's body I can't treat and who's mind I can't touch, well, then my obligation is discharged. They can put him where they will; he won't be bothered, I won't be bothered, and everyone's conscience can remain free and untroubled. And that is my dilemma... what is in his mind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps you're just polishing a stone, endowing this Elephant Man with qualities he doesn't possess?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatiently) And what qualities are those? Intelligence or stupidity?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slightly hurt) I'm sure I don't know, Freddie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry... I don't know either. I just don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, these things take time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've only got until two o'clock tomorrow afternoon, when Carr Gomm meets him. Somehow, between now and then I've got to make John Merrick at least seem like an intelligent man... Why am I fooling myself? Nothing short of John delivering the Sermon on the Mount is going to sway Carr Gomm...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick is propped up in bed. Suddenly the door bursts open. The Night Porter, an arm around a drunken giggling tart, stands in the doorway. As soon as the Charwoman sees Merrick, she screams as does Merrick, and she wriggles free, making for the stairs. The Night Porter watches her go and then turns to Merrick laughing noisily. He then pulls the door shut with a bang. Merrick, very frightened, crawls down into his hiding place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Anne alone in bed, asleep. Treves is finished dressing and leaves the room. The sound of the door closing awakens Anne. She looks around for Treves. A clock reads 5:30.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick's disguise hangs on the wall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want, he maketh me to lie down in green pastures; He leadeth me beside still waters. He restoreth my soul: He Guideth me in the paths of righteousness...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Righteousness...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Righteousness for his namesake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Very good, very good. Now, when your visitor comes today I want you to say it exactly the way you said it just now. I will introduce him to you and you will say the words you've learned. If you have any trouble with any of the words, I'll help you. I'm sure you'll be just fine. If you do as well for him as you've done for me these last two days, then I'm sure our visitor will be very pleased. Now, let's go through the whole thing again, shall we? I will say "May I introduce you to Mr. Carr Gomm." And you will say...
direction.name: direction

result.heading: WE NOW SEE TREVES AND MERRICK TREVES

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, my name is John Merrick. I am very pleased to meet you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves and Carr Gomm are speaking together as they walk along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves cannot easily answer this question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm starts up the stairs. Treves remains behind, watching him for a moment, then follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's only a physical problem. He has trouble with certain sounds because of the constrictive deformity of the mouth. But he can talk, and has a great eagerness to make contact with people who will let him. So if you have any difficulty understanding what he is saying, just tell me and I'll make it clear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Speaking is one thing, Treves, but can the man comprehend?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...As I said, it's only a physical problem... but I do feel that Mr. Merrick is very flattered that you're taking the time and trouble to meet him, and he's most anxious to make a good impression, so he might seem rather nervous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He needn't. I have no desire to cause him any discomfort. Did you make those inquiries we spoke about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I spoke to both the British Home and Royal Hospital for Incurables. I'm afraid that they weren't very encouraging, but they said they'd bring it up at their next committee meeting, so we should have their answers shortly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, fine. You know, your dedication to this patient is an inspiring thing, Treves. But you must remember that this is a hospital, and there are many patients here. Patients who can be made well, and you owe them your first consideration. Just don't become so obsessed, old man, that you begin to neglect them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick is standing beside his disguise on its hook. He nervously smooths the cloak down, repositions the Bible on the bedside table and smooths the cloak again. He looks at the door, expecting it to open. It doesn't. His hands smooths the cloak over and over again. Voices can be heard outside the door. Merrick freezes. There are two raps at the door. Merrick flinches, clutching the cloak. The raps are repeated. He pulls himself together and walks to the middle of the room. He takes a deep breath and closes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens and Treves and Carr Gomm enter. Carr Gomm's eyes are rivited on Merrick, but he contains his shock. Merrick is breathing unevenly, his eyes still closed. Treves goes to him and touches his shoulder. Merrick opens his eyes and looks up at Treves. Treves turns to Carr Gomm, as does Merrick. Carr Gomm lowers his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm, still shaken, instinctively offers his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Carr Gomm can withdraw his hand, Merrick grasps it with his left hand. There is an uncomfortable silence. Merrick releases it. Carr Gomn, nervously clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is another agonizing silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is at a loss. This is not part of the expected scenario.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick doesn't seem to understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm stares levelly at Treves for a moment, then asks Merrick:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves stiffens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick looks at Treves for guidance, but Treves cannot look him in the eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves and Carr Gomm go out the door onto the landing. Merrick sees his chance escaping him and tries to recapture their attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves and Carr Gomm are alone on the landing, speaking quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick has come to the end of what Treves taught him to say. He makes one last, desperate attempt to be heard. Treves, disheartened, stands on the landing as Carr Gomm starts down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves is staring, open-mouthed, back into the room. Carr Gomm looks up at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves rushes back into the room, followed by Carr Gomm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a long silence as all three men stare at each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John, may I introduce you to Sir Carr Gomm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello... my name is John Merrick. I am very pleased to meet you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very... pleased to meet you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How are you feeling today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel much better. Thank you for asking. And you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm feeling very fit, thank you. How is your bronchitis?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel much better. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you comfortable here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone has been very kind. I am extremely grateful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Merrick likes the food here. Don't you John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes! It is much better than what I am used to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) And what was that, John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Potatoes...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Carr Gomm) ...Yes potatoes... but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the variety of food here is very pleasing... I commend you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) I understand that you were beaten?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no, everyone has been very kind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I meant in your former situation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm feeling much better now...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me, how do you like Mr. Treves? As a teacher?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I... everyone has been very kind to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course. How long did you and Mr. Treves prepare for this interview?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...everyone has been very kind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course... Well, it's been a pleasure meeting you, Mr. Merrick. Good day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to John) Thank you, John. You did very well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his voice is gaining strength) The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want. He maketh me to lie down in green pastures... (he continues through the following dialogue)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was a nice try, Treves, but the man is so obviously mouthing your words.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I'm very sorry to have wasted your time, sir. I just felt that I had to do anything I could to protect him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry too. He simply doesn't belong here. He's be much happier somewhere else, where he could be constantly looked after. Believe me, Frederick, it's better that it worked out this way. Good day.
dialogue.name: dialogue
