dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) (now full voice) Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil, for Thou art with me; Thy rod and Thy staff, they comfort me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it, Treves?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Thou preparest a table before me in the presence of mine enemies, Thou anointest my head with oil...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't teach him that part!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My cup runneth over. Surely goodness and loving kindness shall follow me all the days of my life, and I shall dwell in the house of the Lord forever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you, know the rest? I never taught you the rest of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me, John, how did you know the rest of the 23rd Psalm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitantly) I... I used to read the Bible every day. I know it very well. The Bible, and the Book of Common Prayer. The 23rd Psalm is very beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A few minutes later. We hear voices inside the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens and Carr Gomm and Treves come out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm stops on the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It was a great pleasure to meet you, Mr. Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am very pleased to meet you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope we can talk together again sometime. Good day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Merrick) I'll be right back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to see you in my office as soon as you're through up here. We've a good deal to discuss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, sir. Thank you, thank you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Treves. Well done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not me, sir. Mr. Merrick. He succeeded in spite of my shortsightedness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick is on the bed, propped up by pillows. The door opens. Treves comes in, shuts the door and leans against it. They look at each other for a moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why did you let me go on like that, teaching you what you already knew? Why didn't you tell me you could read?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You did not ask me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never thought to ask. How can you ever forgive me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no do not say that. You have been so kind to me. I was afraid to say too much. People always want me to be quiet. You wanted me to speak, but I was afraid. Forgive me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We do have a lot to talk about, don't we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm is seated at the window, looking out silently. There is a knock at the door and Treves enters. He quietly closes the door and walks to the window. Carr Gomm never moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm suddenly stands and faces Treves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can you imagine what his life has been like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I think I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No you can't. You can't begin to know, no one can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are quite right, Treves, this is an exceptional case. And I quite agree that the committee should see Mr. Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could easily arrange...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, not that way. Broadneck and the others don't like to deal with patients directly. It makes them queasy... Do you have any photographs of Mr. Merrick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excellent. We shall present them, along with the other particulars of the case to the committee. I want them to see, exactly, how horribly his body has been affected. You and I shall vouch for his inner qualities.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think they'll go along with us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course they will. They're reasonable men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick is in bed, very tired. It's been an exhausting day. Suddenly the door opens and Mothershead comes into the room. Merrick looks up at her very apprehensively. She walks over to the bed, picks up the Bible from the table, opens it and hands it to Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick looks down at the Bible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mothershead backs slowly to the door, deeply disturbed. She stares at Merrick for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She quickly turns and exits. Merrick looks down at the Bible. It is open to "Lamentations".
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Read it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thou heardest my voice; hide not thine ear at my breathing, At my cry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Credit where credit is due. You'll have the paper every morning at breakfast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON (NIGHT) As before the lights are going off in one hallway after another. The hallways are empty, dark and silent. We hear the great iron door close with a bang.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is in his bed as always. He holds the portrait of the beautiful woman, gazing at it longingly. He hears a door close far away in the silence of the hospital. Suddenly we hear the heavy footfalls of the Night Porter's boots. As they get louder and louder we move slowly closer to Merrick's face. The sound is very close now, and Merrick's eyes are visibly agitated. Finally, the door bursts open and the Night Porter is standing there. He stares malevolently at Merrick for a long moment and then walks to him menacingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs Merrick fiercely by the hair and jerks his head back. Merrick immediately starts to wheeze and gasp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls Merrick all the way down onto the bed, so that he is prone, struggling for breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Night Porter is as first surprised, and then pleased at the desperate sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Satisfied, the Night Porter rights Merrick who is just able to catch his breath. The Night Porter smiles and pats Merrick on the shoulder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I hear you have some trouble sleepin'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Head's too heavy, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I heard a nasty rumor about you; I heard you can talk but you can't, can you... can you... can you?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (struggling) Noooo!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... No you can't! One word about me out of that stinking cakehole... Just ONE word, and you'll have no trouble at sleepin'... no trouble at all. You understand me? Do you!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (croaking) Yyyesss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There now, that's better, i'n' it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves and Carr Gomm are on their way to the committee meeting, confident of their position. Treves is holding a folder, and Carr Gomm is looking at the photographs of Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves is silent. They stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They continue walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at the pictures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They go through a door marked "Committee Room".
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: As far as I can see, the only obstacle might be Broadneck. He has enormous influence over the others, very old school, not an easy man to impress. In any case, if worse does come to worse, we still have the British and Royal Homes to fall back on, don't we.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, we don't. Their committees have informed me that they're unwilling to take Mr. Merrick, even if they were supplied with funds. They don't want him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's up to us then, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry Treves, we'll make them see it our way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They've eyes, haven't they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON HOSPITAL We see a pair of hands. One of the photographs of Merrick is passed to them. They hold it for a moment, then lay it down flat on the table. One of the hands covers the photograph with a piece of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We pan up from the hands to see BROADNECK, his face pinched with disgust. He sniffs, and gazes coolly at Treves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm, from his chair on the committee, pounds his gavel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm and another committee member raise their hands. Broadneck is displeased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the committee members says "I quite agree". Carr Gomm scowls a bit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm raises his hand. None of the others do. Treves and Carr Gomm exchange hopeless glances. Carr Gomm looks at the man who had originally raised his hand. He looks away, ashamed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Broadneck and the rest raise their hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm cannot conceal his contempt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others cough their agreement and hurriedly leave the room. Treves walks over to the committee table and takes the paper off the photograph. He stares sadly at Merrick's picture.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...Due to the progressive nature of the disease, I feel sure that the patient does not have much longer to live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive the redundancy, gentlemen, but there is no other place for him. Both the Royal Hospital and the British Home have turned him down even if sufficient funds for his care were provided. The workhouse is certainly out of the question. The patient has an overwhelming fear of returning to the horrors of his past. His appearance is so disturbing that all shrink from him. He cannot, in justice to others, be put in the general ward of the workhouse. The police rightly prevent his being exhibited, and he is mobbed in the streets wherever he goes. What is to be done with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: for one, am sick and tired of this competitive freak-hunting by these overly ambitious young doctors, trying to make names for themselves. To parade then about in front of the pathological society is one thing, but to waste this committee's valuable time with requests for shelter for these abominations of nature is quite another.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, John Merrick is not an animal, he is a man, fully aware of his condition. An intelligent, sensitive, literate man, with an intimate knowledge of the Bible. His horrible infirmities do not reduce him to anything less than what he is, a man; and it would be criminal if we of the London Hospital, his final refuge, the last place on earth where this man can find peace, were to cast him out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, may I make a suggestion. There are two small rooms off Bedstead Square that are no longer in use and would be admirably suited to Mr. Merrick's needs. I also propose to write a letter to The Times, appealing to their readers for assistance. Knowing the generosity of the British public, I feel we would have little trouble in raising the funds for his maintenance. Indeed, this hospital's rules do preclude the admission of incurables, but if ever there was an exception to the rule, it is this patient. So therefore, I propose, if Mr. Treves is finished, that we put it to a vote. All those in favor of keeping Mr. Merrick here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One moment, (showing the picture of Merrick) as far as I'm concerned this creature has no business being in our hospital. I think Mr. Carr Gomm's letter would be an excellent idea, (to Carr Gomm) and when you appeal for funds, I think you should appeal for a more appropriate place for him as well. I agree the British public is generous, and I'm sure that somewhere the creature will find a happy and permanent home, but not here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see. All, then, that move we keep Mr. Merrick here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All those opposed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (triumphantly) Well then. In the meantime, of course, he needn't be turned out. He may stay in the rooms off Bedstead Square until such time as more suitable arrangements can be made, thus freeing the Isolation Ward for more deserving patients. Well then, Mr. Chairman, if there is nothing further to discuss, I move that we adjourn this meeting and all go bout our normal business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I second the motion gentlemen. This meeting is adjourned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Somehow I don't think they quite understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a very lovely WOMAN seated in a chair before a mirror. She is reading aloud from The Times. Her hair is being brushed by a YOUNG GIRL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns to the girl thoughtfully.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...terrible though his appearance is, so terrible indeed that women and nervous persons fly in terror from the sight of him, and that he is debarred from seeking to earn his livelihood in any ordinary way, yet he is superior in intelligence, can read and write, is quiet, gentle, not to say even refined in his mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd very much like to meet that gentleman. He sounds almost Shakespearean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON The room is elegantly furnished and heavily carpeted. The walls are panelled in richly gleaming walnut with finely wrought brass lamps spaced regularly along their length. In the center of the room is a long oak table with a fine linen table cloth, around which sits a number of Doctors, among them, Fox. Some of them are still eating. A waiter is clearing away a few plates and several Doctors are helping themselves to port wine kept in decanters in the center of the table and to cigars in humidors. One of them is reading The Times. At one end of the table sits Treves, picking at his food. #1 DOCTOR "...in life until he came under the kind care of the nursing staff of the London Hospital and the surgeon who has befriended him..." #2 DOCTOR Good publicity for the Hospital, at any rate. #3 DOCTOR Treves comes off well too, eh Freddie? #4 DOCTOR It was pleasant of you to join us this evening, Frederick. #2 DOCTOR Your Elephant Man dining out this evening? #4 DOCTOR I understand the kitchen ran out of hay this morning. The group laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a short pause. #4 DOCTOR The Elephant Man. Makes you sound rather more like a zoo-keeper than a surgeon, Frederick. The group again laughs. Treves clears his throat and rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves leaves the room. #4 DOCTOR I say, what's he on about? #3 DOCTOR He's getting a bit of a swelled head, if you ask me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A deep silence falls over the Doctors.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (slightly sourly) Do continue reading, Mr. Stanley, please. #1 DOCTOR "...it is a case of singular affliction brought about through no fault of himself; he can but hope for quiet and privacy during a life which Mr. Treves assures me is not likely to be long,"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me gentlemen. I seem to have lost my appetite. Good evening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) Well, no one did ask you Atkins. Frederick Treves is not only the most skillful surgical operator here, he's also a humanitarian of the highest order. You sound like a pack of whining school boys with your petty jealousies. #3 DOCTOR Look here, Fox, I simply said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh belt up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a small, very dusty, dirty room, filled with boxes and bedsteads and other things stored over the years. The one grimy window is locked shut. The door opens and two middle-aged CHARWOMEN enter. They look around at the room with distaste and drop their mops and buckets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She reaches into her apron pocket and pulls out a pint bottle of gin. She takes a drink and passes it to her friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The 1st Woman takes the bottle and walks across the room. She forces open the balky window and sits on the sill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The 1st Woman, laughing, takes another healthy swig from the bottle. We see past her through the window, the dark silhouette of the main spire of St. Philip's Cathedral against the sky. It fills the screen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There are cleaner rooms in the gasworks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's all the fuss for, then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wiping her mouth) Don't you know? It's for that strange one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves' Elephant Man? I hear he's got a trunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right, right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Blimey, now we're cleanin' up for circus animals!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick sitting on his bed, hunched over in concentration reading an Illustrated London News. He is staring at a picture of the Eddystone Lighthouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at the picture silently. There is a knock at the door. Merrick says, "Come in". Treves enters, holding a book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds the book out to him. It's an "Alice In Wonderland".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lovingly feels the leather binding and looks at Treves with speechless gratitude. Merrick carefully opens the book to a colored frontpiece, the picture of Alice grown too large for a hallway, looking imploringly at the dwarfed White Rabbit. The caption reads "...curiouser and curiouser". He leafs through the pages looking at the other illustrations as Treves, delighted with the gift's effect, looks on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves smiles broadly and exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves' words have disturbed Merrick. He sinks into the pillows, the book before him. We see the picture of the Mock Turtle perched upon his rock, great tears rolling down his cow-like face, as Alice and the Gryphon look on with intense sympathy. Merrick looks up at his disguise hanging on the wall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reading softly)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: silent shaft of stone on a deserted promontory, the lonely Eddystone is a beacon of aid and comfort to mariners of all nations."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening. How are you feeling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening. Very well, thank you. And you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very well, thank you. I have something for you, John. I'm sure you'll enjoy it, it's very popular.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) Thank you... so much... oh it's beautiful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I came to tell you that I'll be here early tomorrow morning. We're moving you to your permanent home. I'm sure you'll be very happy there, John. So get a good night's rest, there'll be new people to meet tomorrow. Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weakly) Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - WHITECHAPEL The Night Porter enters and saunters over to the noisy crowd. As they welcome him, he slaps down The Times on the bar counter for all to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Night Porter has the undivided attention of the people in the pub.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lifts his glass to his lips. We move back to see Bytes' boys who, having heard the Night Porter's words, slips unnoticed from the pub.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here... listen to this. This is a letter to THE London Times from the guvnor of the hospital. (starts to read) There is now in a little room off one of our attic wards a man named John Merrick, so dreadful a sight that he is unable even to come out by daylight to the garden. He has been called The Elephant Man on account of his terrible deformity...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...His appearance is so terrible that woman and nervous persons fly in terror at the sight of him. (pauses) ...and guess who can get you tickets to see him? Your own Sunny Jim!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's go see him, then!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep your shirts on. (shaking his finger at them) ...When the time is right. Right now he's in the attic but tomorrow they're movin' him into Bedstead Square, right into my lap... then... for the right price you'll see something you'll never see again in your life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wheezing) Workhouse!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick, in his disguise, and Treves, one arm around him, are walking together. Merrick seems very uneasy. A Nurse, on duty early or late getting off, passes them. She stares at the hooded figure. They continue on in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room is now spotless. It is furnished with a bed and the required pillows, a small table and chair by the window, now curtained. Adjoining this room is a smaller one which contains a bathtub. Merrick enters and looks around, confused. Treves stands in the doorway. Merrick turns to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick pulls off his hood. His eyes are bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick's eyes glisten with held back tears. He lowers them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick inspects his new home. He seems pleased-by the bathtub, by the table, by the window to the outside world. Merrick pulls the curtain aside and opens the window. He looks out and then up with a small intake of breath. Before him, beyond the hospital fence, the spire of St. Phillips Cathedral stands resplendently in the morning light.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is your new home, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This... is my new home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) The hospital?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course! What did you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost sobbing) How long will I stay here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I promise you. You will never see the inside of that horrible place again. You will never, ever go back to the workhouse... or that man. It's a splendid room, don't you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I'm next moved may I go to a lighthouse?... or to a blind-asylum?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see Carr Gomm walking to his office. He is met at the door by an anxious Treves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm goes back into his office and Treves walks off. MERRICK'S ROOM (A WHILE LATER) There is no one in the room. The bathroom door opens and Nora and another nurse enter, carrying buckets which they set down by the hall door. They straighten up and lean back against it. Mrs. Mothershead enters from the bathroom, speaking over her shoulder to Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girls try to keep bright faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mothershead starts to exit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick quietly enters the room, dressed in a billowy white shirt and baggy black pants. The two nurses try to smile, but he cannot look at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kathleen's eyes go wide at the sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick looks down at himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girls leave, taking the buckets. Merrick, alone, walks about the room getting the feel of his new clothes. There is a knock at the door and Treves enters.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Has the response picked up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frankly, Treves, it's not what I'd expected. A few small cheques. Well- wishers. Don't worry, these things undoubtedly take time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he's so afraid he's going to be carted off. I've promised him that won't happen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... I'll let you know if there's something in the afternoon post.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I think I can safely hand the duties over to you girls now. Mr. Merrick will require a bath every day... that way he won't pong quite so much. Nora, you can instruct Kathleen on the finer points of Mr. Merrick's bath. You'll be on your own tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't look so glum girls. Such enthusiastic volunteers should be more cheerful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, and girls, under no circumstances are there to be any mirrors brought into this room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's... so ugly!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ugly or not, you're going to help me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Feeling better now, Mr. Merrick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You look very nice in your new clothes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if there is nothing more, I suppose we'll be leaving you now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You look splendid, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When one is invited to tea, one must look one's best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The door opens. Merrick, disguised, enters, followed by Treves who closes it and hangs up Merrick's mask on the coat rack. The mirror has been removed, leaving a faint outline on the wall. Merrick is enchanted by the house. Treves takes him by the arm and leads him into the sitting room. Anne appears at the top of the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves comes back to the foot of the stairs and smiles up at Anne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anne manages a smile, comes down the stairs and together they go into the sitting room. Merrick is examining everything in the room. Nothing in this almost magical world escapes his attention. The furniture, the personal mementoes, particularly the pictures on the fireplace. He turns around when he hears them enter, lowering his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anne is startled, but conceals it very well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anne extends her hand. John takes her hand and looks up very slowly meeting her eyes. Anne smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, Merrick bursts into tears. Anne is at a loss as to what to do. Merrick takes his hand from hers and covers his eyes, weeping pitiously. Treves puts his hand on Merrick's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves and Anne exchange worried looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anne goes now to get the tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick cannot answer through his sobs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Make yourself comfortable, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come and meet our quest, my love.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John Merrick, I'd like you to meet my wife, Anne Treves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) I'm very pleased to meet you, Mr. Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John... what's the matter? John... why are you upset?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sobbing) I'm not used to such kindness. From a beautiful woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you like a nice cup of tea, Mr. Merrick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still sobbing) Yes... thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, a cup of tea would go nicely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John... would you like to see the rest of the house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come with me, John. I'll show it to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Anne is composing herself by busily fixing the tea and cakes. She stops for a moment, takes a breath, and then resumes her activity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Treves and Merrick coming down the stairs. Merrick is calm now. They go into the sitting room, where Anne is just setting the tea tray out. Treves ushers Merrick to a highbacked sofa and sits him down. Merrick is very shy of Anne. Treves and Anne sit on the other side of the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anne serves the tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves and Anne laugh good-naturedly. Merrick's face, as always, is quite blank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves goes to the fireplace and takes down a few pictures. He hands a picture of the girls to Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick sets the picture down carefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches into his cloak and brings out the small portrait of the beautiful woman. Treves is absolutely amazed. Merrick gently hands the picture to Anne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this, Anne is so extremely touched that she begins to cry. She tries to hold it in, but to no avail. She reaches a hand out to Merrick and he takes it. He tries to comfort her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Anne goes on, as Treves, in wonder, watches her and Merrick locked together in the communication of intense sympathy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Merrick, sugar?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes please, two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One or two?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John loves the house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes. You have so many nice things, and so much room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, we do have a lot of room. But you should see the place on weekends, when I see patients here. Sometimes there are so many, we have to set them down wherever we can. In fact, Mrs. Treves sometimes says that the only room she can call her own is the bedroom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (earnestly) Well, it's a lovely bedroom. What do you call that thing above the bed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a canopy, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ohhh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How is your tea, John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's very good. I'm enjoying my visit with you very much. It's so very kind of you to have me as a guest in your home. I'm sorry I made a spectacle of myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not at all, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love the way you've arranged your pictures on the mantlepiece. Is that the way it's done in most houses?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are they of?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, our relatives... the children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The children! May I see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as if looking at an icon) The Children. Where are your children
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, they're gone for the day... with friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the word gives him pleasure) Friends. Ah yes, friends! How nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And here is one of Frederick's mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How lovely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And here are my mother and father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They have noble faces.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a cord is struck) I've always thought that myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ever so timidly) Would you... would you like to see my mother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled) Your mother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... why Mr. Merrick she's beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She has the face of an angel... She was an angel. She was so kind... so kind to me. It's not her fault, for in the fourth month of her maternal condition she was knocked down by an elephant. I'm sure I must have been a great disappointment to her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (visibly touched) Oh no, Mr. Merrick. No. No son as loving as you are could ever be a disappointment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If only I could find her. If only she could see me now, here, with such lovely kind friends. You, Mrs. Treves, and you, Mr. Treves. Then maybe she would love me as I am. I've tried to hard to be good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please... please...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON Merrick, in the dimly lit rear hall, is huddled over a trash can tucked underneath a stairway. He pulls out a discarded drug box. He holds it closely to his chest and goes into his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick goes to his table and puts the box down. He hangs up his disguise, then goes back to the window and pulls the curtains aside. Moonlight bathes the table, illuminating the portrait of his Mother. John seats himself and sets the box in front of him. He reaches for a pencil, and then begins to draw windows on the front of the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nora is coming down the hall with a breakfast tray. She stops at Merrick's door and raises a hand to knock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick, as before, is hunched over the table, pencil in hand. The sides of the box are covered with carefully drawn windows and archways. There is a knock at the door and Merrick, startled, looks up. Nora enters and puts the tray on the table. She glances at the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and walks to the cabinet for linen and bath supplies. She opens it and takes out a clean towel and a blanket. She pauses, and turns to look back at the table. Merrick is concentrated on his work. Nora, curious now, walks to the table. Merrick, conscious of her presence, leans back in his chair and looks up at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick points through the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick points out toward the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sets the towel and blanket down as she leans closer to inspect the box. She points to a circle drawn on top.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nora looks at the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick, at a loss, shrugs his shoulders. The movement makes Nora aware of his body, and he is the Elephant Man once again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She quickly exits. Merrick watches her go and then turns back to his work. He sees the towel and the blanket. He turns quickly to call after Nora, but stops himself. Merrick takes up the towel and blanket, walks into the bathroom, and carefully drapes the towel over the back of the bath.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this that you're doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing at the box) What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? Oh! I see! It's St. Phillips. Oh, of course. Why... why that's very good, I mean you've gotten the windows and arches just right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it's so good, I mean... it's so very good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you... very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where did you get this box?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The hallway? Oh, the wastecan! MERRICK I meant no harm, it was the only place where I could find cardboard. I thought it has been thrown away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's alright, it was thrown away. No one wants it. It's just that it's a little dirty, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The main spire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The... oh, the spire! How silly of me, it's as plain as day... Mr. Merrick, where did you learn to do this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I learned a long time ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, but how will you finish it? You haven't any more cardboard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll have to find some more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncomfortably) Yes... well, good day, Mr. Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick is at his table working on his cathedral. There is a knock at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is a trifle apprehensive, but he agrees. Treves ushers MRS. KENDAL through the door. At the sight of her, Merrick's eyes go wide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She-hands Merrick a nicely framed picture of herself. Merrick is speechless, overjoyed by the gift.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He places it, with great care, next to his mother's portrait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves smiles at them. Merrick is a trifle nervous but Mrs. Kendal smiles at him and he relaxes a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She produces a beautiful leather-bound volume of Shakespeare's works. Merrick takes it with reverence and begins to leaf through it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick finds a place and begins to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick, embarrassed by these last words, starts to close the book. Mrs. Kendal knows Juliet's lines by heart. She looks at Merrick for a moment, then replies tenderly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick pauses, looking at Kendal, then continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both look at each other for a long, silent moment. Treves is touched and amazed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John, there's someone here who would like to meet you. Would that be alright?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John, I'd like you to meet one of the brightest lights of the British stage, Mrs. Kendal. Mrs. Kendal, John Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good day, Mr. Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good day...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've brought you some things. I hope you'll like, Mr. Merrick. I hope you don't think it too forward.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew you'd understand. Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to know that I don't go about giving my pictures to just anyone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no. I would never think it! It's so beautiful. You are so... I'll give it a place of honor, here, next to my mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's very pretty, your mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves says that you are in the theatre. Do you live there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no, Mr. Merrick. I just work there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, even to work there would be wonderful. Is it beautiful?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've never been?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alas, no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well you must go. It is one of the most beautiful places on earth. Of course, I'm rather partial.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me about it, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's very difficult to put into a nutshell, but I should say the theater is the shrine of the imagination, where one may suspend disbelief and travel anywhere in the world, to any time you desire. You may look over the shoulders of kings, unobserved, battle with ruthless tyrants, and marry the beautiful princess, all in the space of a few hours. Onstage you may be whoever you wish to be, do anything you please, and always, always live happily ever after. The theatre is all the brightest and best things of the world, Mr. Merrick. It is lights and music, gaiety and joy. It's... well, it's romance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the magic word) Romance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's one thing the theatre has in great store. which reminds me. I have something else for you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you read it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but I certainly shall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Romeo and Juliet. I know of this... "If I profane with my unworthiest hand, This holy shrine, the gentle fine is this: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand, To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much, Which mannerly devotion shows in this; For saints have hands that pilgrims hands do touch, And palm to palm is holy palmer's kiss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do. They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, Mr. Merrick, you're not an Elephant Man at all...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no... no... you're a Romeo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - WHITECHAPEL People are happily drinking and singing and laughing. Bytes and the boy are keeping a watchful eye on the Night Porter, who is making a deal with a couple of men at a table. They hand over a few coins and follow the Night Porter out of the pub. Bytes finishes his beer and thumps the glass down on the bar. He wipes his mouth with his sleeve and he and the boy casually follow the other three men out. Bytes and the boy stand by the pub door, watching the men cross the street and go to the back gate of the hospital which the Night Porter unlocks, and leaves unlocked, but closed, behind them. They walk into Bedstead Square, laughing quietly. Bytes crosses the street and goes to the gate. He walks along the iron fence and watches the Night Porter and his "customers". He stops and waits to see where they go. The Night Porter stands the two men before a window and motions for them to wait. He goes through a door into the hospital. After a few moments the window opens wide, and there, neatly framed and silhouetted, stand Merrick and the Night Porter, gripping Merrick's neck. The two men outside start back in shock, but stand mesmerized by what they see. We hear the laughter of the Night Porter echo across the empty square. Bytes smiles broadly and says softly to himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So, there you are, my boy, my treasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a small circle of women having tea and gossip. One of their daughters, off to the side, is reading a newspaper society page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has got the women's attention.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mummy, listen to this!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hush, Jennifer, can't you see Mummy's talking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it's about Mrs. Kendal, mummy! The actress you go on so much about!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Mrs. Kendal, always at the forefront of fashion and form, was seen leaving The London the other afternoon. No, dear readers, the most facile actress of our day has not been taken ill, but rather said she was 'visiting a friend'. And who was the lucky recipient of this attention? Quick enquiries proved it to be none other than Mr. John Merrick, The Elephant Man, with whom our readers are undoubtedly familiar. After a chat of three-quarters of an hour, Mrs. Kendal was kind enough to leave Mr. Merrick with an autographed portrait of herself. Owing to a disfigurement of the most extreme nature, Mr. Merrick has never been properly presented to London society. But knowing that wherever Mrs. Kendal goes, others inevitably follow, the questions arises: Will London society present itself to him?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A carriage draws up in the street outside the hospital. A nicely dressed woman sticks her head out the window, looks around and scowls disappointedly. Nearby is parked another carriage and driver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They drive off. Above Merrick's bookshelf we see a row of framed pictures of prettily smiling society women. Mrs. Kendal has started a fad. We pan slowly by them and down to Merrick's table where his Mother and Mrs. Kendal have their place of honor. The cathedral is also there. Beside it is a modest tea service. We now see a GENTLEMAN standing behind a seated LADY. They hold teacups. They are both very attractive and empty-headed, and seem on the verge of screaming. They smile at Merrick who has been talking the whole while. Merrick holds an elegant, silvertipped walking stick across his lap, and admires a ring that only fits his little finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Lady and Gentleman nod nervously. John takes the teapot from the service and refills their cups. The Lady's hand shakes, rattling the cup against the saucer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the smiling pictures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the picture of Merrick's Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We draw close to his Mother's picture.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to her driver) Parkins, whose carriage is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well mum, that looks like Alexander, Lord Waddington's driver.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lord and Lady Waddington! Well. Drive back to the house. (indicating her clothing) I can't be seen in this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for your kind gifts. I can't say enough about this ring. And this walking stick is ever so dashing. So much more elegant than my old one. More tea?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you have a chill I can close the window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no, no, no, I'm fine. Please... I mean, thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't get out as often as I'd like to, for some people DO find my appearance disturbing. Of course, I can't fault them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) People are often frightened by what they don't understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And it is hard to understand, even for myself, for you see, Mother was so very beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) How's your tea?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves walks the Lord and Lady, their faces locked in terrible silence, to the door. Mothershead, at her desk, watches them pass with great disapproval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they turn to go, their faces drop, their loathing undisguised. Treves closes the door. He goes to Mothershead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to go. Mothershead steps in front of him, detaining him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (under her breath) Watery headed bunch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I regret that I must leave you here, m' Lord, m' Lady. Thank you so much for coming. It was an act of the greatest charity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no, Mr. Treves, the pleasure was all ours. Good day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Incredible, isn't it? Well, I think John has had enough visitors for one day, Mothershead. I've got a lecture at the college, I'll be back this evening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, sir. I'd like to have a word with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh?... Well, quickly please, Mothershead, I'm overdue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't understand why you let those people go in there, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now Mothershead, you have to understand that this is very good for John. He relishes contact with people outside the hospital...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you saw them, sir. They couldn't hide their disgust. They don't care anything for John, they're just trying to impress their friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't you being just a little harsh, Mothershead? You yourself hardly treated John with much loving kindness when he first arrived.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I bathed him, didn't I? I fed him and cleaned up after him! If loving kindness can be called care and practical concern, then yes, I did treat him with loving kindness, and I'm not ashamed to say it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right, Mothershead, please forgive me... Of course, I appreciate everything you've done for John, and I'm glad that you are concerned about his welfare. But, I'm the physician in charge and I must do what I think best. I'm also very late, so please forgive me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you ask me, sir, he's just being stared at all over again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We pan across Merrick's bookcase, now quite full, and we see a few titles: "Moll Flanders", "Emma', "Jane Eyre", "Pamela", and then to Merrick. He and Treves are reading poetry together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick closes his book and sits silently for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves is taken aback. He considers, then says tentatively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick rises. Treves ponders over what Merrick has just said. He looks at Merrick and something very odd happens. Merrick is looking levelly at him. For the first and only time, we see expression on his face. It is a calm, knowing look, almost a benign smile. At that very moment there is a bright flash of light behind Merrick's head, seemingly from the window. Treves blinks, unable to comprehend what has just happened. When he looks again, the moment has passed. Merrick, his back to Treves, moves to the bookcase to replace the volume.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a knock at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nora enters with a brown paper parcel tied with string. Merrick says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts the parcel on the table and opens it. We see several squares of new cardboard, a cutting knife, a pastepot, and a few brushes and some paint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick examines the materials with reverence, and thanks her profusely. Treves is moved and a little disconcerted. Merrick lays the things aside carefully and begins to pull the crude spires from the discarded box. Nora smiles at the busy Merrick and exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves notices to his dismay that the growths on Merrick's head are larger. He finds it very difficult to disguise his concern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is silent. He goes over to his cloak, reaches into it and pulls out a folded up advertisement. He hands it to Treves, who examines it closely. It is an advertisement for an-elegant gentleman's dressing bag, boasting ivory brushes, silver fittings and Moroccan silk lining.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When will the stream be aweary of flowing under my eye? When will the wind be aweary of blowing over the sky? When will the clouds be aweary of fleeting? When will the heart be aweary of beating, and nature die?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never, oh! Never, nothing will die. the stream flows the wind blows the heart beats Nothing will die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves, there is something I've been meaning to ask you for some time...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Can you cure me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No John, I can't. I can care for you, but I can't cure you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought as much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you looking for me, Sister?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No sir, Mr. Merrick. (to Merrick) I have something for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought these things would be helpful with your cathedral.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The cathedral is coming along nicely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bending over the model) Yes, soon I will start the main spire, but I must finish these columns first, How kind of her!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How blind of me. Is there anything else, John, anything at all that I could get for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no! There is nothing! I have everything, you have given me everything I could possibly want. I am happy every hour of the day. I only wish there was something I could give to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please John, it would give me so much pleasure to give you something. Something just for yourself. Isn't there something you would like to have?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want a dressing bag, John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't think it's too gaudy, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Mothershead finds Treves walking slowly down the hall, looking at the ad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves, some more books arrived for Mr. Merrick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Mothershead. Have a porter put them in my office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir. (seeing the ad) What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A dressing bag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very smart indeed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. John wants it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A dressing bag?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't think it's too gaudy, do you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John thinks it's very dashing. Something no gentleman should be without. I'm inclined to agree.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A dressing bag?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick is still at his cathedral working away. Suddenly, he looks up at the window and the Night Porter is standing there smiling wickedly, pointing a finger at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Night!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves is standing by a table on which are two stacks of books. Treves selects books from the stacks and puts them into a box. Treves looks troubled. He takes one from the pile and examines it. It's a copy of "Frankenstein".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Getting no response, she enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She holds him in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see from Treves' eyes that he is not reassured.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You stay with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling from the next room) Dinner will be served, shortly, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: More romances for John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (far away) Hmmm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Freddie! What's the matter? You've been like this all evening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... I've just been thinking about something that man Bytes said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Freddie. What could that wretched vampire say to upset you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That I am very little different from him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh that's absurd, Frederick. No, no Frederick, that's all wrong! John is happier and more fulfilled now than he has ever been in his entire life. And, that is completely due to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But why did I do it? What was this all for? So John Merrick could live out his last days in peace and comfort? Or so I could become famous?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frederick, just what is it that you are saying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Am I a good man or am I a bad man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh Frederick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a good man. A very good man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON It is very dark. There is a dim red glow coming from the holes in a furnace door. We hear a door open and footsteps coming downstairs. A man comes into the basement carrying something large and black. He approaches the furnace and opens the door. The man is Treves. He is holding the stiff black surgeon's coat of which he was once so proud. He looks at it for a moment, and then stuffs it into the furnace. Inside, the coat starts to smoke heavily, then bursts into flames. Treves watches it burn, and then closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON HOSPITAL We see Carr Gomm walking down the hall to his office. Broadneck appears, going the other way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Broadneck walks on. Carr Gomm goes into his office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ahh! Broadneck! You'll no doubt be pleased to know that we've received a smashing response to my letter. It's all very heartwarming, though several letters do mention how beastly it would be to part the poor fellow from Mr. Treves and the staff, but since the committee insists...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (scowling) Good day, Carr Gomm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mothershead is standing by the desk looking through a small stack of mail.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is this all there is for John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid so, Mrs. Mothershead. Perhaps tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see in a pair of hands holding a buff colored envelope embossed with the Royal Seal. We follow the hands down the hall to a door where one of the hands knocks next to the "F.C. Carr Gomm" sign, then enters the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm and Mothershead look up to see a porter with the buff envelope enter. Carr Gomm takes the letter and the porter exits. Carr Gomm opens the letter and reads, his expression changing from concern to delight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm hands her the letter. Never having touched Royal stationary before, Mothershead handles it delicately. She begins to read.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it? What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE LONDON Broadneck and the other committee members are seated at their table, anxious to get the meeting underway. They talk among themselves. The door opens and Carr Gomm and Treves enter. Treves seems quite nervous, but Carr Gomm is relaxed and smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves sits and Carr Gomm takes his place at the head of the table and raps his gavel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Broadneck explodes to his feet. Carr Gomm smiles at Treves, who looks quite grim.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you think this is a bit premature? We don't have the backing yet to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Steady on, Treves. Have a seat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, I know we begin every meeting by reading the minutes, but in the interest of speed I think we should conclude a matter discussed previously, to wit, that of Mr. John Merrick, the Elephant Man...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Broadneck?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Chairman! I was under the distinct impression that we had concluded discussion of this disagreeable matter. Had we not ascertained that an Elephant Man is not acceptable as a patient? Have we not, very generously, allowed the creature to use two of our rooms until such time as he could be properly disposed of? Have we not...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick is working on his cathedral, painting details with a very fine brush. As he lifts the brush from the paint jar, a drop falls on the table. Merrick carefully lays down the brush and wipes up the spilled paint with a cloth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I must be more careful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Which brings to mind my next point. The rules, gentlemen, the rules. In a society such as ours, it is of paramount importance that we not stray from the established order. Has that order not already been fearfully strained by allowing this... this... sideshow exhibit to take up residence, however temporary, in two very useful rooms, the purpose of which would be far better served in accommodating treatable patients, patients to whom this hospital was originally dedicated? I believe we have a duty... Carr Gomm still smiles. Treves is about to spring to Merrick's defense, but Carr Gomm catches his eyes and motions for him to remain silent. Treves is perplexed. Carr Gomm checks his pocket watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick as before, busily working away. We see a ladybug crawling slowly across the roof of the cathedral. Merrick notices it and watches for a moment, then reaches up and lays a finger alongside the bug. The bug crawls onto his finger and Merrick holds it closer to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Ladybug, ladybug, fly away home... it's cloudy out, I know, but remember; behind the clouds there is always the sun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a Royal carriage glide to a stop in front of the hospital. A footman jumps down and opens the door. A very elegantly dressed woman begins to emerge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Broadneck is still talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Broadneck turns to Carr Gomm. Carr Gomm checks his watch and clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Broadneck blusters with rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm smiles and again checks his watch. Treves is very nervous.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...In light of these facts, our course is clear. The question is not whether to accept this creature as a patient, the question is when will those rooms be vacated for use by better qualified, more deserving cases? I move that this Elephant Man be removed from the premises immediately. We have a sacred duty to cure the sick, not care for circus animals. That is my last word on the subject. Mr. Chairman, shall we vote?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I take it, Mr. Broadneck, that your mind is fixed on this matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Chairman! Don't you have ears? I am unalterably opposed to any...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see two nurses, their backs to us, walking down the hall. They start to go in a doorway when they stop suddenly, very startled, and curtsey deeply. Mothershead comes into the hall, also curtseying madly. She is followed by the elegantly dressed woman, who is followed in turn by two footmen. They walk regally down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...No, my mind is made up on this, and I am resolved to stand firm. You shall not sway me. May we now vote, Mr. Chairman, at long last? Carr Gomm checks his watch. The door to the room begins to open. He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two footmen enter the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The elegantly dressed woman enters. Everyone rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alix seats herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Broadneck seems very unnerved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carr Gomm raises his hand. The other members, puzzled, look at Broadneck. Quite red in the face, Broadneck looks at Carr Gomm, then to Treves, then to the Princess. He seems to almost deflate, then slowly raises his hand. The other members, now thoroughly confused, raise their hands as well. Carr Gomm bangs his gavel, smiling broadly. Treves is almost beside himself with happiness, and the Princess is obviously very pleased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Broadneck, humiliated, cannot look at anyone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I believe that time has come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, Her Royal Highness Alexandra, Princess of Wales.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, gentlemen. I hope I am not interrupting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indeed not, your Highness. Your presence is always greatly appreciated. We were just about to put the matter of Mr. Merrick to a vote. (he turns to the other committee members) The Princess is very interested in Mr. Merrick's fate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indeed I am sir, as is the Queen. I have a brief communication from her Highness which she has requested I read to you: To the Governing Committee, London Hospital. I would very much like to commend you for the charitable face you have shown Mr. John Merrick, the Elephant Man. It is laudable that you have provided one of England's most unfortunate sons with a safe and tranquil harbour, a home. For this immeasurable kindness, as well as the many other acts of mercy on behalf of the poor, of which Mr. Carr Gomm has kept me informed, I gratefully thank you. Signed Victoria, Empress of India, Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. (looking straight at Broadneck) I am sure you gentlemen may be counted on to do the Christian thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you very much, your Highness, you may be sure we shall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well then, I move that Mr. John Merrick be admitted to the London Hospital on a permanent basis, on condition that the Hospital shall receive a yearly payment equal to the cost of occupying one bed, and that the funds for his care shall be clearly separate from hospital funds. All those in favor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The motion is carried.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, now we may go about our normal business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick is working on his cathedral. It is almost finished. He is detailing the spire, carefully painting in the stonework. There is a knock at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves enters carrying a wrapped parcel, followed by Carr Gomm, and Mothershead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves defers to Carr Gomm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is speechless. He just looks from Treves to Carr Gomm to Mothershead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick finds it very difficult to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick looks about him at his rooms. It's beginning to dawn on him that this is indeed his, that at last he has a real home, a place of his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves hands Merrick the package. Merrick carefully pulls off the wrapping paper. Treves smiles. It's the dressing bag. Merrick is overjoyed with the gift. He lovingly handles the articles, taking them in and out of their compartments opening and closing the bag.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please, come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling broadly) Good afternoon, John, Mr. Carr Gomm has something he would like to say to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Merrick, it is my great pleasure to welcome you, officially to The London Hospital. The Governing Committee this morning voted unanimously to provide you these rooms on a permanent basis. This is your home now. I'm so very, very pleased for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you see, John, there's no need for a lighthouse. All your friends are here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Welcome home, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...my... home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You did this for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please... please thank the governing committee for me. I will do my utmost to merit their kindness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying the words on for size) My home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is one more thing, John. Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it the one you wanted?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mr. Treves. Mr. Treves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure? Because I can take it back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves. Thank you my... friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clouds billowing, moving swiftly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is alone, wearing his cloak and standing by the table, cradling the dressing bag. He takes each article out of the bag and lays it carefully on the table, all in very neat order. He stares at the elegant objects, then rearranges them. Merrick picks up the toothbrush, examining it with a sort of reverence. He does the same with the ivory-handled razors and the comb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WHITECHAPEL There's a good crowd in tonight; lots of drinking and shouting and glasses breaking. Several of the neighborhood "working girls" are having a bit of a rest, looking for a laugh. The Night Porter is rounding up customers, his pockets ringing with coins. People have their hands raised urging the Night Porter to take them along to see The Elephant Man. The Night Porter goes to a table where a MAN sits with two of the girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others all moan their disappointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bytes, sitting at his usual place at the bar, sees that tonight is his chance. The Night Porter rounds up his "customers", all twelve of them. Bytes saunters over to the Night Porter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bytes drops several coins in the Night Porter's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The whole group happily leaves the pub, several still holding their gin bottles. The Ladies are rather unsteady on their feet. As they all leave, the Night Porter says:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here now, these lovely ladies ain't never seen it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Man) You're on mate. (to all the others) Alright, alright, that's enough for this performance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hang on, hang on, there's always tomorrow night. Not to worry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Room for one more?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the right price...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, let's be off then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quietly now! Quietly! We don't want to scare him. (he laughs)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (Merrick as before) he reaches over to the picture of Mrs. Kendal and picks it up. We see his face reflected in the glass. Merrick sets the picture down on the table. He takes up one of the silver brushes and, using the picture as a mirror, neatly brushes his hair over his monstrous skull. He lays the brush down in its specific spot. Merrick takes his ring and puts it on his left hand. He opens the cigarette case and stuffs one into his right hand. He takes up his walking stick, breathes deeply, then walks around the room in a slow circle. Merrick is transforming himself. Merrick comes back to the table and examines his reflection in the picture. With the ring, the stick, the cigarette and his neatly brushed hair, Merrick is the very image of a dashing young man about town. He inclines his head to the picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this moment the door bursts open. The Night Porter stands grinning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is frozen, caught. Seeing Merrick in his outfit, the Night Porter's jaw drops. They both stare at each other. The Night Porter begins to laugh hysterically. Merrick frantically begins to put away his dressing bag articles. When Merrick starts taking off his ring, the Night Porter comes over to him and grabs him by the cloak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Night Porter drags him by the neck to the window. He throws the window open out in the square is the waiting audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He strips off Merrick's cloak. The audience gasps. A few people who have been before laugh and clap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts kissing each whore. The crowd is mesmerized. Bytes moves in behind the Man with the Whores.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Man begins to laugh. The Whores laugh drunkenly and halfheartedly resist being taken in to see The Elephant Man. As they are pushed through the door,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Whores reluctantly enter the room. The Night Porter laughs at their discomfort. The Man notices all of Merrick's pictures of women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lets one of the whores go and grabs the other one from behind at the wrists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Night Porter has turned Merrick and is holding him for the approaching kiss. The crowd is egging them on. The man forces the Woman closer and closer and raises her arms to force her into an embrace. As Merrick and the Woman touch, being pressed together, the Woman begins to scream. The Night Porter, the Man and the crowd all laugh with glee. Merrick and the whore now have their faces pressed together. The Whore is screaming and Merrick is crying out and screaming too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick and the Whore are pushed onto Merrick's bed. The Night Porter grabs the other Whore now. She begins screaming wildly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes the screaming Whore down onto Merrick. Her screaming face goes right into his. Merrick tries to move away and as he does his head goes too far back and his cried turn to horrible wheezing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd outside is trying to see in the window. Five or six more have gone into Merrick's room to see. All are laughing and screaming and trying to get a close look at The Elephant Man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick recognizes his voice and looks frantically around for his former owner. The Night Porter pulls Merrick up by the window again. He then begins pushing the crowd out the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly one of the crowd outside reaches up and grabs Merrick's good hand and pulls him half out the window. Others follow suit and haul him all the way through.
