The cathedral falls to the floor, breaking into several pieces. Because of the horror of touching him, the crowd outside lets Merrick fall to the ground. The Night Porter whirls around and sees that Merrick is gone. He pushes the rest of the people outside and quickly goes to Merrick, lifting him to his feet. Unseen by anyone, Bytes slips into Merrick's room. Merrick is now standing. The crowd moves in. The Night Porter is enjoying the festivities, but looks around nervously for trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Man grabs Merrick and pours some gin into his mouth, then pushes him away. He's caught by another man, fed liquor and pushed away. He's pushed now from person to person faster and faster. Finally Merrick falls to the ground, dizzy and a bottle of gin on Merrick's head. He coughs and moans through the wheezing. The crowd is now strangely silent circling The Elephant Man like a pack of dogs closing in on a terrified rabbit. Suddenly Merrick starts to wail. The crowd joins in and they hoist him above their heads, screaming with laughter, around and around, joining him all the while. Now we see a window reflecting the scene of terror. A curtain is pulled aside and we see through the reflection the face of the Young Porter, watching everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is lowered down into the crowd. it parts and the Night Porter emerges walking Merrick toward us to his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd moves through the iron gate of Bedstead Square. In the background we see Bytes' boy sitting on top of a wagon. The Night Porter takes Merrick into his room and puts him on the bed. He drunkenly stumbles about trying to out the room in order. He places the smashed hulk of the cathedral back up on its table, inadvertently leaving the spire and a few columns on the floor. He picks the cloak up and replaces it on the peg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a purse full of coins out of his pocket. He removes one small coin and flips it on the floor in front of Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Night Porter turns and leaves. Merrick, alone now, hears the Night Porter's echoing footsteps and the distant sound of the gate being closed. There is a long silence as Merrick collects himself. He then leans back into his pillows with a deep sigh. His eyes close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick's eyes flash open. We see Bytes coming toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bytes lifts Merrick up off the bed. He reaches out for Merrick's cloak. We slowly PAN over all the smiling women's faces as we hear the following:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rustling sound. We now glide slowly on to Merrick's Mother's picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick's good hand comes into the frame trying to reach his mother's picture. He grabs at the table cloth and pulls. Now we see Bytes gripping Merrick's arm and pulling. We see the picture fall to the ground with a THUD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : In the sky the heavy clouds are moving. CUT:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, my name is John Merrick. I am very, VERY pleased to meet you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Curtain time!!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no! You look lovely. Don't change a thing, darling. You look like the bleedin' Prince of Wales.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My friends... The Elephant Man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing and clapping) Horrible... I told you it was horrible... just horrible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Man) Perhaps the ladies would like a closer look?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on Jack... No... No, don't. (laughter) Etc.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Cor, he's a real ladies' man, come on... give the ladies' man a kiss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, you'll give him a kiss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still laughing but a trifle scared) Come on, Jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here that's enough romance. Now into bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A prince needs a harem!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mind his head... You'll kill him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (yelling) Quiet down. Quiet down. You'll have the whole place down on us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (outside, yelling loudly) Bring him out then, so's we all can see him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone outside!!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give 'im a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O. THE REFLECTION) Here now... Here now... He's had enough... show's over!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the crowd behind him) Meet you at the Peacock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bring your friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs drunkenly) He's had 'is fill for one night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Merrick) I did real well tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here... buy yourself a sweet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) My treasure...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't you glad to see me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bytes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Get into your cloak... (rustling sound) ...now, your hood... do it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...Alright.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Morning sunlight on the floor of Merrick's room. We move slowly around, discovering the church spire, the columns, the penny and Merrick's mother's picture. Over this, the sound of knocking on the door. Through the door, we hear Treves calling, "John?... John?" More knocking. The door opens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves surveys the empty room. Quickly he goes into the side bathroom. He comes out with a very worried face. He goes to the cathedral model and is horrified by its condition. He finds the spire and then Merrick's Mother's picture. He quickly leaves the room and walks down the hall. The Young Porter, waiting in the hall, approaches Treves and stops him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now we see Mrs. Mothershead entering Merrick's room surveying the same scene. Her face hardens as she sees the picture of Merrick's Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now we see Treves filled with anger. He's got the information from the Young Porter and bolts down the hall at full speed. Mothershead, still in Merrick's room, now become activated with determination to get to the bottom of all this herself. She leaves the room. In the distance is Treves marching off. Closer to her is the Young Porter, looking worried. She calls him to her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good God... John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -UP of Treves angrily walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Mothershead leaves the Young Porter, furiously marching off in the same direction as Treves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Night Porter is adding fresh coal to the operating room stove. The old coals were still quite hot and now smoke begins to rise. The Night Porter takes up the bellows and begins to pump the coals into a blaze. The door bangs open and Treves is there, standing stock still, in a cold murderous rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Night Porter, frightened by Treves' intensity, begins to sputter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves stalks over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves takes the Night Porter by the arm and begins to drag him out. The Night Porter throws his hand off violently, whirls around, his back to the door, and seizes the poker from the stove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves, blind with fury, tears the poker from the Night Porter's hand, and is on the verge of using it. Unbeknownst to them, Mothershead has storm into the room, just in time to hear the last of the Night Porter's speech. Without a break, she strides over to him and with a lightning movement, boxes him soundly on the ears. The blow is staggering and makes quite a formidable sound. The Night Porter falls to the floor, barely conscious.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . MERRICK?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... I don't know what you mean, Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't lie to me. I know all about it. You were SEEN. Where did you take him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take him? Now wait... I didn't take him anywhere. We were just having some fun. We didn't hurt him... just having a laugh, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I left him, he was in his bed, safe and sound.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! You tortured him. YOU TORTURED HIM, you bastard. WHERE is HE?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (enraged)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! I ain't done nothing wrong. People pay to see your monster, Mr. Treves. I just take the money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! YOU'RE THE FREAK! GET OUT! YOU'RE FINISHED!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have a care, Mr. Treves. I ain't afraid of you! You and your bleedin' Elephant Man! I'm glad what I did! And you can't do nothing! Only Mothershead can sack me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves is standing in the street looking at the now bare shop front. He walks to the window and tries to clean a small circle in the glass. He peers in. From inside, through the smeared dirty window, we see Treves' distorted face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O. THROUGHOUT) I'd like to think I felt no less for John than you, Treves, but face the facts, the man has disappeared, very likely to the continent. There's no question of your going after him, you're desperately needed here by your patients. Remember Treves, you did everything in your power... everything in your power.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A moving circle of light in blackness. As we move closer to the light, it becomes distinguishable as a peephole in the side of a wagon. Through the peephole we see a dark overcast sky. It is dusk. We move even closer to the hole. Just beside it we see the head of a horse with blinders on moving alongside. We move closer still to see its rider, a policeman. He notices the peephole and leans forward in the saddle, looking in. From outside, we see the peephole and an eye gazing out. The eye is replaced by a plug. The policeman starts back and pulls up on the reins. As he falls behind we see the portrait of the E.M., from the front of the shop in London, on the back of the wagon. The policeman looks at the poster. The wagon moves on out of frame and the policeman slows his horse to a stop. The wagon is being driven by Bytes. The boy sits beside him. Another policeman rides abreast of him. They ride a few yards more and then the policeman stops by a sign at the fork of the road, reading "AALST 30 km". "Brussells 80 km." The policeman gestures for Bytes to move on. The wagon continues down the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Bytes and the boy are riding along the road. Bytes turns in his seat and opens a hatch in the roof. He looks down in. Inside the wagon, lit by the last dregs of the sunset, is Merrick, huddled in his sleeping posture. He feels the light and looks up weakly, wheezing, obviously very sick. A small bowl of potatoes sets untouched beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He snaps the hatch shut and turns forward muttering to himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Still haven't eaten, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bytes... please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eat, my treasure, I want you healthy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm beginning to feel your weight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & ROAD (MORNING) We see a field with a road in the distance, leading to it. It is misty, the sun barely peeking through the rolling clouds above. On the road, the wagon is plodding toward us. At the bottom of the frame a FEMALE PINHEAD in a dress comes into view. She is watching the wagon. A DWARF comes into view beside her. She points to the wagon and she and the Dwarf excitedly confer. They turn back to watch its progress and the Dwarf reaches up and takes the Pinhead's hand. We move back slowly to reveal a ring of circus wagons in the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: comes up to the two other Freaks and watches the wagon. We pull back further to see a small circus. There are little stalls, and cages containing two mangey lions, some screeching spider monkeys and some squawking parrots. The circus is abustle in the drab grey field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -UP of the Pinhead jumping up and down in her excitement. There is a clap of thunder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A rainstorm over the freak show. We pass along the row of freak wagons. These freaks truly deserve the name. They are quite different from the rather domestic ones we saw in the circus in England. These are not fakes. A rope cordons us off from them. The audience, which we see all around us, is enjoying the freaks, but there is a sense of vulgarity in their gaiety. They seem hard, and cold and jaded. We move by pinheads, a Hermaphrodite and a Legless Wonder. Some Siamese Twins are playing cat's cradle. Past them runs a Dwarf with a plumed hat playing a small flute. Trailing behind him on a string is a small wooden ark on wheels. A lionfaced man is combing the hair that covers his face. A Rubber Man pulls the skin of his neck up over his face. There is a fairly big crowd standing around a Tall Man, affectionately rubbing the Small Parasitic Twin, growing out of his chest. The Barker-Owners compete with each other and the occasional thunder. Finally we hear the patter of Bytes, telling of the horrible fate of John Merrick's Mother on that African Isle so many years ago. A very big crowd is listening to him. They are looking at the poster at the back of the wagon, waiting impatiently to see the Elephant Man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He raps twice with Merrick's silver-tipped walking stick and pulls the poster up. Merrick is standing unsteadily in the wagon. He is quite sick. The audience gasps and shudders. A few shrieks are heard. The Elephant Man is always the Elephant Man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick slowly turns around, the audience gasping at the sight of the horrible tumors. Bytes raps the walking stick twice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick begins a series of awkward movements, his pained version of a dance. Without his walking stick it is very difficult for him, but he strives to do it. Some of the crowd laughs at this, others shudder at the strange sight. Suddenly Merrick falters and comes to a stop, breathing irregularly. Seeing this, Bytes goes to him and bringing the stick behind Merrick, out of view of the audience, jabs him savagely in the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick groans with pain and some of the people in the first row flinch back. Merrick begins to dance again as people throw coins onto the stage, which the boy gathers and puts into a cap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...The result is plain to see. Ladies and Gentlemen... THE TERRIBLE ELEPHANT MAN!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turn around!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The poster is rolled up, Merrick on the floor of the wagon wheezing horribly. Beside him on the floor is a bowl of what looks to be slop and potatoes. Bytes is standing at the back of the wagon looking down at Merrick. He picks up the bowl and jabs it at Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick looks wearily at the bowl but makes no move to accept it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick closes his eyes. This really enrages Bytes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He jabs the bowl at Merrick, almost as if he'd shove it down his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this last word he throws the contents of the bowl splattering in Merrick's face. He stands for a moment looking down at Merrick who has lapsed into a coughing fit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Eat, my treasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angry) Eat. I said eat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eat, damn you. EAT! EAT!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said EAT!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There is a small crowd gathered in a circle on the grass. Merrick stands amidst them on a small wooden stool, Bytes jabbing him from behind again. Merrick is making a strange moaning cry, slightly reminiscent of the trumpet of an elephant. The boy is passing amongst the people with a cap, collecting coins. Merrick lifts his face to the sky, the sound of his own misery mingling with his elephant call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the poster of the Elephant Man. Bytes stands before it saying the last of the patter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He raps twice with the walking stick and pulls the poster up. Merrick is now extremely sick. He almost looks as if he is unable to stand. The audience, as always, is quite alarmed. Bytes smiles and comes forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick looks incapable of even this simple movement, but he slowly manages to turn. The crowd reacts to the horrible condition of Merrick's back and head. Bytes satisfied that the Elephant Man is having the proper effect, raps the walking stick again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick's eyes look painfully up to the heavens and he begins to shuffle clumsily about the platform. Without his stick this is very difficult for him, causing him great pain. It is a humiliating spectacle and the crowd unimpressed by the halting movements of the monster begins to heckle him. Bytes seeing that the dancing isn't being received well moves to place a stool next to Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick, already exhausted by his little dance, wheezes and coughs, attempting to ascend the stool. It is useless, he is just too tired. Again the audience shouts its disapproval, booing and hissing the Elephant Man. Bytes curses and raps again, demanding obedience from Merrick who again bravely tries to mount the stool. He cannot do it! Bytes, striving to save the moment and please the angry crowd, goes to Merrick and roughly helps him up. Merrick teeters precariously on the stool. Bytes raps the stick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick hesitates and Bytes bangs the stick on the wagon. The audience quiets down to hear the elephant call. Merrick senses this lull, but he is very frightened and sick. He lifts his head wearily and makes a few wavering cries that sound very little like an elephant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick tries again but there is no improvement. The crowd begins to jeer at Merrick, exhorting him to make the call of the elephant. Merrick is now almost swaying on the stool. He attempts to step down, but as he does it finally becomes too much for him and he collapses into a heap on the wagon floor. The crowd is no longer in the least bit challenged by this piteous mess and they break out into a vocal fury, throwing objects at the wagon. Bytes is humiliated at first, and then is quickly angry. He turns to Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Merrick just lays there moaning and wheezing irregularly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He jabs Merrick a few times with the silver-tipped walking- stick. The crowd jeers even louder still. There is a clap of thunder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The result is plain to see. Ladies and gentlemen... THE TERRIBLE ELEPHANT MAN.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turn around!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rapping) Up! Up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give the call of the elephant!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Louder!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get up you miserable bastard!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (realizing it's no use) I'm beatin' a dead horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bytes is seated by a campfire drinking from a bottle of wine. He is very drunk. From the wagon behind him we can hear Merrick coughing and wheezing. We also hear the boy, almost pleading with Merrick to stop coughing and to try to eat. As Bytes listens he gets angrier and angrier. Finally he rises clumsily to his feet and stumbles over to the back of the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy is crouched over Merrick, who looks little better than a corpse. Bytes points a menacing finger at Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches in and grabs Merrick roughly by his arm, dragging him out of the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drags Merrick across the way to a small monkey wagon. The boy follows, his face filled with sympathy for Merrick. Bytes opens the cage door and stuffs Merrick in as the monkeys scream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He slams the door and latches it. Then he quickly turns, still in his rage, and starts for the wagon. As he passes the boy, the boy tries to stop him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bytes knocks the boy down with the back of his hand. He stalks to his wagon and climbs inside. After some muffled sound, Merrick's food bowl comes flying out. There are more muffled sounds as Merrick's stick, cloak and hood are also thrown out one by one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy looks to Merrick who is in a panic trying to keep himself away from the monkeys who scream loudly in all the excitement. We hear Bytes, cursing to himself, in the wagon. The boy, frightened, goes to the fire and pulls a blanket around him. Merrick crawls to one corner of the cage away from the screaming monkeys. Suddenly one of the braver ones leaps at Merrick with a scream, biting him on the arm, and moving quickly away. Merrick yelps with pain and struggles to move away. The other monkeys have gotten the idea now and they begin to move warily toward Merrick, screeching threateningly. Another leaps out and clings to Merrick's shoulder, biting and scratching furiously then he too jumps away. Merrick cries out. Now the monkeys are getting braver and more and more of them lash out at Merrick with their paws. They jump onto him with savage screams, biting him on the head and neck and shoulders. Merrick's eyes search for escape. The monkeys come on and on without a break, screaming madly all the while. With his good hand Merrick begins to pull himself up with the aid of a bar. The monkeys strive to pull him down. Merrick looks through the bars at the wagon and screams frantically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Bytes won't come. Something is happening inside Merrick. A wave of feeling is growing, coming from a place in him very deep down and far away. This feeling seems to give him strength and he is able to pull himself all the way up in spite of the hairy moving mass that now seems to cling to every part of his body. The feeling is surging up inside Merrick making his body shake uncontrollably as if he were a volcano about to erupt. The monkeys keep on biting and screeching, pulling at him. Suddenly a formidable cry rings out of Merrick's mouth, with a power and assurance we have never heard from him before. He whirls about and cries out again a shattering "No", the force of which scatters most of the monkeys away from him onto the cage floor, dumbfounded. Merrick grabs a monkey who has managed to hang and throws it into the group of monkeys on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The monkeys have been shocked into silence, pushed into the other end of the cage. Merrick, perhaps as surprised as the monkeys, rests against the bars of the cage. The monkeys make no move toward him. They sit across the cage from Merrick silently watching him with fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Another bleedin' heart!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sly bastard. You're doing this to spite me, aren't you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aw, Bytes, he's sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's doing it to spite me, I tell you, and it's got to stop!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's sick, Bytes. He's going to die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (enraged) If he does it's his own fault! But I'm not burying that swollen bag of flesh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll show you! I'll show you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bytes, please...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bytes! Bytes, please!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! I AM NOT AN ELEPHANT! I AM NOT AN ANIMAL!! I AM A HUMAN BEING! I... AM... A MAN! I AM A MAN!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We now see Merrick crouched in a corner of the cage in his sleeping position. We see the monkeys again, and hear whispering in the still night. CU of merrick's head resting on his knees. The whispering continues and a shadow falls across Merrick. Merrick begins to stir, his head comes up, and he looks around. The whispering stops. We pull back to see some of the freaks from the circus gathered around the monkey cage in a small group. They are: 2 pinheads (male and female), the dwarf we saw earlier with the plumed hat and the ark on a string, another male dwarf, a female midget, a lion-faced man, and an armless wonder. The female pinhead reaches into the cage and pats Merrick's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks to the lion-faced man and speaks to him in a foreign tongue. The lion-faced man unlatches the cage door. Then, after further instruction, from the plumed dwarf, the freaks gently help Merrick out of the cage, closing the door behind him. The dwarf speaks to the others again and the lion-faced man and the armless wonder move to each side of Merrick. The lion-faced man pulls Merrick's right arm over his shoulder. Merrick puts his left arm around the armless wonder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and the other dwarf light two lanterns and they begin to move off. The boy by the wagon has awakened. He sees the small caravan of freaks moving in the darkness, the light from the lanterns bobbing over the grass. His first instinct is to call for Bytes, which he almost does, but then he thinks better of it. He rises and goes to where Bytes threw Merrick's stick and disguise. He nicks them up and goes to the small band of strangely shaped beings. They stop and watch him warily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick looks the boy in the eye, and the boy holds his gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The small band moves away through the wagons. The boy watches the lantern light receding in the darkness. He turns and looks to the wagon, the poster of the Elephant Man, and the dying fire. He moves to the fire quickly collecting a few blankets and belongings. Then taking one last look at the garish poster just visible in the night, he runs off into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE SILENT FACES OF THE MONKEYS

dialogue.raw_text: You alright?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: y-y-yes--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Want to come out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're English.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course! You want out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Won't be a moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've decided... You've got to get away from here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (handing over the things) Here... you'll need these.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good of you, mate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Merrick) Good luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But... but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be alright.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see the beams of the lanterns moving through the trees like will-o-the-wisps. They help Merrick along, the plumed Dwarf directing them from time to time. As they move along we see them pass a small still pond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The intrepid freaks approach a bend in the road. They go around the corner and before them stands a small train station, a train sitting amongst the steam by a platform. The freaks stop just outside the light of the station and the plumed Dwarf's instruction get Merrick into his disguise. The female pinhead, who has carried his stick, hands it to Merrick, squeezing his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The plumed Dwarf relays the message and the freaks respond to Merrick in their language.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and confers with the freaks who all rifle through their pockets and produce some coins. Then he and Merrick walk into the station, the freaks watching and waving.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, my friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll go in with you, you'll need a ticket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The train is about to leave. At a barrier two ticket collectors are taking tickets of a few last-minute passengers, who hurry off. The Plumed Dwarf and Merrick appear and walk to the barrier. The Plumed Dwarf hands over the ticket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk off down the platform. The collectors stare after them. The Plumed Dwarf, his arm around Merrick, is helping him down the platform, as fast as possible, his ark trailing behind him. As they pass the windows of the first-class carriages, we see the ornate interiors and the happy, handsome people on their plush seats. The Plumed Dwarf finds an empty compartment and opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks down the platform. The Ticket Collectors are watching them with great interest. Merrick climbs laboriously aboard. The other people on board see Merrick, react, and move away from him as far as they can in the cramped, 3rd class carriage. The Plumed Dwarf notices this and sniffs at the people with contempt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grins. The whistle blows and the train slowly begins to move off. The Plumed Dwarf still holding the door open, walks along with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick nods "yes", and holds out his hand. The train is moving a little faster. The Plumed Dwarf grabs his hand and they shake. He shuts the door. As the carriage passes, Merrick's mask is pressed up against the window. The Plumed Dwarf waves to him as the train moves away. He looks at the train for a moment, then walks back down the platform.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just going to help my friend on board.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This'll do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry I could only get you a third class ticket, but it's all we had.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no, my friend...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say hello to London for me. I miss her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, I saw you once there, in London. You're a great attraction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Luck, my friend, luck. Who needs it more than we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR Merrick is in the corner, facing into the carriage. He looks slowly around. The other passengers have moved away, forming almost a moat of space around him. We see the whole carriage now; the cowering people and Merrick at the far end. Seeing their silent, horrified stares, he moves to the opposite seat, facing the back wall. Merrick looks around for a moment, then sees his reflection in the window. He stares at himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The carriage is dark now, and empty except for Merrick. He looks out the window at a sign above a station platform that says "Oostende", and at the few people still walking about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the side of the carriage. Merrick, inside the darkened car, is not visible. A CONDUCTOR walks to the end of the carriage and turns a valve. He opens the door to Merrick's compartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick is motionless, reluctant to leave the security of the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick pulls his walking stick from the darkness and plants it firmly on the floor with a loud THUD. The Conductor, expecting violence, draws back. A few people on the platform, who have stopped to watch this exchange, gasp. Merrick rises with the help of his stick, and slowly descends from the carriage watched very carefully by the others. He looks around for a moment, then walks off down the platform. TWO YOUNG TOUGHS follow a little distance behind him, laughing and mimicking his uneven gait.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, you'll have to leave now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is the end of the line, you'll have to leave now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a short line of people waiting to board a cross-channel steamer. The First-Mate is standing by the gangplank, smiling at the women passengers and making the most of his handsome face and crisp white uniform. He surveys the line, stops and smiles even more broadly. A very pretty Young Woman at the end of the line is smiling back. We see the end of the quay disappearing into darkness towards the station. The rhythmic sound of Merrick's stick is heard as he slowly moves into the light. The Woman, still smiling at the First-Mate, demurely lowers her eyes. Merrick appears behind her, breathing heavily from the long walk. The woman's face freezes. She turns her head, ever so slightly, and sees Merrick. Her face drops. The First-Mate sees the Woman change, then sees Merrick. He walks out of frame. Merrick is still trying to catch his breath as the First-Mate walks up. The Woman looks up at the First-Mate imploringly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick, confused at first, produces his ticket from his cloak. The First-Mate examines it and hands it back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick remains motionless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He points down the quay. Merrick turns and walks away. The Woman smiles gratefully at the Fist-Mate, who tips his hat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: May I see your ticket?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, there's no room for you on this ship, you'll have to wait for the next one, in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You heard me. There's no room. Now be off with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: are sitting against the wall, drinking and singing. One of them gets up and walks out of frame. Merrick peeks around a corner at the Drunk. They stare at each other for a long moment. Merrick disappears. The other Drunk comes back, sits down, and they both start singing again. Merrick is in darkness, seated around the corner, tapping his left hand against his leg, keeping in time with the drunken music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Merrick behind some crates, watching the ship. On the wharf a different First-Mate waits until the last of the morning passengers board the ship. He then nods to the Ticket Taker and ascends the gangplank, nodding to a crew man. On board, everyone prepares to get underway. Merrick pitches forward from behind the crates, half running, half stumbling toward the Ticket Taker. The Ticket Taker, about to board the ship, drops the tickets on the ground and stoops to pick them up. As he collects the scattered tickets a hand comes into frame holding a ticket out to him. He reaches for it, and calls over his shoulder to the crewman at the plank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns back and finally takes a look at the late arrival.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His mouth drops. Merrick hurries past him. The crewman now also sees the passenger as he begins his clumsy ascent of the gangplank. The shrill ship's whistle blows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wait! One more!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll have to hurr...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick is crouched in a dark corner underneath a stairway, his head resting on the points of both knees, his arms clasped around them. He is asleep. A few drops of rain fall and hit his cap, then a few more and finally it begins to rain. He wakes up and looks around. He hears a voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the stairs we see a young couple in the rain at the railing, arm in arm. The Young Woman points. The Young Man turns to her and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They laugh and hug each other and run inside out of the rain. Merrick's hand comes into the shot, grasping a stair and pulling himself up slowly. He rounds the stairs and walks onto the deck looking after the young couple. Merrick walks to the railing and leans over it, oblivious of the rain. We see the cliffs of Dover.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Look! It's Dover!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finally! Dover!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - DOVER The ship's gangplank leading down to a sea of umbrellas. Passengers one by one come down the plank and are swallowed by the crowd. On the dock amidst the umbrellas, we see Merrick. He looks around, then moves off into the crowd. The crowd moves past a sign saying, "To The Trains".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR Through a rain-streaked window we see rolling green countryside. We pull back to see an Elderly Man in a heavy black overcoat with a wide-brimmed rain hat eating an apple. Beside him his wife knits. A few other people similarly clothed are sleeping. We PAN across them to see Merrick at the back of the car watching the Elderly Man eat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR The last car speeds down the track and disappears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grey light filters through the windows in the high canopy ceiling over the trains in the station. The platforms below fill with people as trains arrive and depart. We now see the station with its newsstands, sweetstalls, shoeshiners, and passengers moving to and fro, carrying luggage and looking for their train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is seated on a pile of baggage looking very adult and bored. His MOTHER stands beside him, though we see only a portion of her billowy skirt. We hear her voice in rapid conversation with another Woman. The Young Boy scans the crowd looking for excitement. He sees something. The Elderly Man we saw on the train and his wife are moving past the barrier. The Young Boy slowly pulls a peashooter from a pocket, puts a pea in his mouth, and raises the pipe to his lips. His Mother's hand shoots out and grabs it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She continues her conversation. The Boy looks sour. Merrick is moving past the barrier. He stops to look around and plan his next move. The Boy sees him. He tugs on his Mother's skirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick still looking around, suddenly turns in Little Jim's direction. He sees the Boy tugging at his Mother's skirt and pointing at him. He turns and walks in the opposite direction along a wall stacked with trunks and luggage, trying as best as he can to blend in. Little Jim gets up and moves after him. Merrick continues along the wall. A few people give him a second look, but pass on. Little Jim comes up alongside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick turns and looks at Little Jim. He looks quickly around. We see, across the station, an open archway leading out into a street. Merrick moves away from Little Jim out of frame. Little Jim watches him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two other BOYS join Little Jim. The three of them watch the escaping Merrick, then move off after him. Merrick is frantically trying to make it to the archway. The three boys appear behind him and call out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the boys reaches down and snatches the hem of Merrick's cloak. He lifts it, trying to catch a glimpse of the mysterious stranger. Merrick pulls away and tries to go faster. Relishing the hunt, the boys follow him, taunting him all the way. As they approach the arch, Little Jim, determined now, steps in front of him cutting him off. Merrick comes to an abrupt standstill, shrinking from the boy. Little Jim reaches up to the hood and grasps it firmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lifts the hood and then staggers back onto the floor in a spasm of fear. He lets out a shrill scream. Merrick turns wildly away, looking for another escape. Little Jim's Mother, hearing her son's cries, looks up immediately. She sees Merrick and the howling boy in the middle of the station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick, hearing this, looks in her direction and whirls away. He stumbles toward another archway exit. People, hearing the noise, watch him go. He knocks down a little girl in his flight and she, too, starts screaming. Through the archway comes a bobby. Jim's Mother, now with her son, calls to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick stops at the sight of the bobby. The bobby at the arch, now aware of the commotion, sees Merrick and walks quickly towards him. Merrick changes course, but, a group of men, alerted by Jim's mother's screams, move forward together, cutting him off. They yell at him angrily. One of them darts toward him and grabs a hold of Merrick's hood. Merrick turns frantically away and as he does, the hood is pulled off him. The crowd shouts at him as he goes, following him in wary pursuit. He moves back past the children and Jim's Mother. They all scream and shield themselves from his approach. Another group of people move toward him blocking all escape. Behind him, he sees a door to a urinal. He moves through it followed by the crowd. We hear fearsome echoes inside. Inside the urinal, the crowd presses Merrick toward a wall. They have become angry now. They shout and there is fear in their voices. They hem Merrick in. He looks around hoping for an opening. There is none. He gives a strangled cry and collapses as the bobby pushes his way through the crowd. Merrick puts his good hand over his good ear trying to block out the screams of the crowd.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Little beast! I thought mummy told you not to bring that horrid thing. Can't you behave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mummy! Mummy! Look at that man! His head, it's huge! Mummy, why is his head so big? Mummy? Mummy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do be quiet Little Jim. Can't you see Mummy is speaking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey Mister, why is your head so big?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mister!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mister! Mister!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you answer me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now I'll see you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My son! My son! Help!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop that man! Stop that man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly to himself) I am not an animal... I'm not... I'm not... I am a man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - LONDON HOSPITAL A small room off the Receiving Room. In the center of the room is a low sofa covered with deeply stained, shiny black leather. On it lies a man, groaning softly. Treves is helping a Dresser bandage the man's leg. Mrs. Mothershead appears at the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bobby from the Liverpool Street Station enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The card changes hands.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There's a policeman to see you, Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you Frederick Treves, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves enters and pushes through the crowd. He sees Merrick in a heap on the floor. The SERGEANT gets up to meet him in the middle of the room, but Treves keeps walking toward Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves goes to Merrick who, just coming to, reaches out to him with his good hand. Treves pulls him up, his eyes brimming with tears. Merrick, too, is weeping. Treves embraces him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know this man, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, he's... my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves! Treves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John.... how can you ever forgive me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Treves, Carr Gomm and Mrs. Kendal are walking down a hallway engaged in conversation.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's all arranged. I'll send over some evening gowns for the sisters that you select to accompany Mr. Merrick. You'll be using the Royal entrance and Princess Alexandra herself will be there to welcome him to her private box.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very grateful to you, Mrs. Kendal. This is just the thing to help him forget his ordeal. John will be very excited.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well it is a miracle he ever got back. And, I'm sure, Mr. Treves, under your expert care, he'll have many happy years ahead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I fear not, Mrs. Kendal. Even in the short time he was gone the size of his head has increased rapidly... as is his pain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How awful for John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And yet, not once have any of us heard him complain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he... dying then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. There is nothing more frustrating, nothing that makes a physician feel more useless, than standing by watching his patient deteriorate. And when that patient is a friend, no... no, there's absolutely nothing I can do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's all quite... I've never heard... It's quite...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (understandingly) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick stands before the row of smiling ladies on his wall. He surveys them lovingly for a long moment. He is holding in his hand a bundle of evening clothes, the handsome black bow tie lying on the new silk shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands for a moment, reluctant to leave their company. He goes to his bed placing the clothes upon it, and then to the cathedral. He compares it with St. Phillips outside. He picks up the main spire and gazes at it, but his mind is somewhere else.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You women are such strange and wonderful creatures... Alas, it seems to be my fate to fall in love with each and everyone of you. I especially wish you could all be with me tonight... I'm finally going to the theatre.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...The theatre...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - DRURY LANE We see the whole theatre. It is very ornate. The orchestra is tuning up and the house is filled with elegant, well dressed, handsome people all happily chatting and calling to one another. We see young men and women flirting boldly and generally enjoying each other's company. In the Royal Box Mothershead and Nora in evening gowns sit up front relishing the spectacle. In the back of the box John sits between Treves and the Princess. He is dressed in his evening clothes, his cloak tied over his shoulders like a cape, but he does not wear his hood. The Princess is explaining to Merrick the workings of a pair of opera glasses. He takes them and delightedly spies about the theatre. John is breathless as the house lights dim and the curtain rises. Enter chorus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CUT TO: Treves smiling at John. He exchanges knowing smiles with the Princess. John watches with the unconstrained delight of a child; but his rapture is even more intense and solemn. His attitude is one of wonder and awe, and he often leans forward, panting in his excitement. To John the characters are not actors in make-up and costume, but real people. CUT TO: Mrs. Kendal and an actor dressed as royalty doing the last scene of Henry the Fifth. K. HEN Fair Katharine, and most fair, will you vouchsafe to teach a soldier terms Such as will enter at a lady's ear And plead his love-suit to her gentle heart?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During the above, Merrick mouths the Kings lines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CUT TO: The Royal Box, the Princess and the two friends enjoying the show. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: O for a Muse of fire, that would ascend The brightest heaven of invention, A kingdom for a stage, princes to act And monarchs to behold the swelling scene! Then should the warlike Harry, like himself, Assume the port of Mars; and at his heels, Leash'd in like hounds, should famine, sword and fire Crouch for employment. But pardon, gentles all, The flat unraised spirits that have dar'd On this unworthy scaffold to bring forth So great an object: can this cockpit hold The vasty fields of Rance? Or may we cram Within this wooden O the very casques That did affright the air at Agincourt? O, pardon! since a crooked figure may Attest in little place a million; And let us, ciphers to this great account, On your imaginary forces work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your majesty shall mock at me; I cannot speak your England. K. HEN O fair Katharine, if you will love me soundly with your French heart, I will be glad to hear you confess it brokenly with your English tongue. Do you like me, Kate?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pardonnez-moi, I cannot tell vat is "like me". K. HEN An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: O bon Dieu! les langues des hommes sont pleines de tramperies. K. HEN What say you, fair one? That the tongues of men are full of deceits?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be full of deceits. K. HEN I know no way to mince it in love, but directly to say "I love you". What! A speaker is but a prater; a rhyme is but a ballad. A good leg will fall; a straight back will stoop; a black beard will turn white; a curl'd pate will grow bald; a fair face will wither; a full eye will wax hollow; but a good heart, Kate, is the sun and the moon, or rather the sun and not the moon; for it shines bright and never changes, but keeps his course truly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The chorus steps out to give the epilogue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During the above, the CAMERA moves in on John. Amidst great applause the curtain rings down. Through the curtain comes Mrs. Kendal to renewed applause. She motions the audience to quiet down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gestures toward the Royal Box. There is modest applause as the audience rises and turns toward it. Merrick cannot be seen in the shadows, and the crowd cranes their necks trying to get a glimpse of him. We hear whispers of "Oh look! It's the Elephant Man! The Elephant Man!' run through the audience. Treves turns to John.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick rises and comes forward to thunderous applause. The audience begins to rise and they clap their hands even louder. Merrick is overcome by the applause. Tears run down his cheeks. Treves, Nora, Mothershead and the Princess, filled with pride, beam at John.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thus far, with rough and allunable pen, Our bending author hath pursued the story, In little room confining mighty men, Mangling by starts the full course of their glory. Small time, but in that small most greatly liv'd This star of England: Fortune made his sword; By which the world's best garden he achiev'd.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . KENDAL Thank you for your warm greeting. Ladies and gentlemen, tonight's performance was very special to me, because it was very special to someone else, a man who knows the theatre and loves the theatre, and yet tonight is the first time he's ever actually been here. I would like to dedicate... the whole company wishes to dedicate, from their hearts, tonight's performance to Mr. John Merrick, my dear friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stand up, John. Let them see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no, I couldn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's for you, John. It's all for you. Go ahead, let them see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly, to Treves) I feel as if I've traveled my whole life just to stand here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merrick, in a night-shirt, is seated at his table working on his cathedral. Treves is nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick closes his eyes and his head tilts forward slightly. It seems unbearably large: too large for him to support.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and starts out the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves comes back to Merrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two look at each other silently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrick rises and goes with Treves to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treves smiles at John then walks down the darkened hallway. Merrick watches him for a moment, then slowly shuts the door. We hear the distant echo of Treves footsteps. Merrick goes back to examine his cathedral, looking at it from different angles. He picks up a fine brush, dipping it into the paint, and makes a few final brush strokes. He moves back into the middle of the room and gazes at it for a long time. He lowers the brush to his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cathedral is a masterwork of detail and shading, as if it were St. Philips itself shrunk to a miniature. He goes to the table, dips the brush into the paint and carefully signs his name at the base of the main spire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sighs deeply, lays the brush down on the table and pushes the model towards the window. The movement causes him pain. He puts his left hand up and feels the back of his head. Merrick turns out the lamp and goes to his bed. He looks at the cathedral again, then around at his room. We see in the dim light his books, his gallery of smiling women, his dressing bag, his cloak and hood, and finally his mother's picture on the table. A slight breeze billows the curtains. We move in very close to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : High altitude... roiling clouds with lightning flashes and low thunder. The sky is in turmoil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lightning flash... thunder roll. The clouds are mingling and scattering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clouds erupt, pushed onward and onward... they slowly begin to calm as... they turn slowly into... elephants linked trunk to tail moving slowly away from us...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The elephants are calmer than the skies we saw... they keep moving onward and onward...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A lacy curtain has taken the place of the sky. The elephants seem to be moving on it... into the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Knock, knock sound. The curtain moves to one side wiping the elephants away with it. There is no terrified audience behind the curtain. There is only light and Merrick's Mother smiling a calm and benign smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The light grows brighter and brighter until we cannot see John's Mother anymore. It almost blinds us.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wasn't Mrs. Kendal wonderful? I can't blame the King for wanting to marry her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will the cathedral be finished soon, John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, very soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Splendid. it's truly a masterpiece. Well, I suppose I'll be on my way now. I hoped your enjoyed yourself this evening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes! It was wonderful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad, John. Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Treves, tell me... tell me truly. Is it alright, did I make any mistakes that you can see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at the cathedral) No, John, not one that I can see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I shouldn't change anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, I wouldn't change a thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I'll walk you to the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight John. Sleep well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You too, my friend. Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is finished.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John... Merrick!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) When will the stream be aweary of flowing under my eye?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) When will the wind be aweary of blowing over the sky?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) When will the clouds be aweary of fleeting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) When will the heart be aweary of beating....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...and nature die?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never, oh! Never, nothing will die; the stream flows, the wind blows, the cloud fleets, the heart beats...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing will die.
dialogue.name: dialogue
